                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">HART1605</h1>
<p class="p">This course provides an introduction to the changing role of painting in
artistic practice from the advent of the nineteenth to the end of the
twentieth century. Visiting museums such as the National Gallery,
the Courtauld Gallery, Tate Modern, and Tate Britain, each week we will
look closely at specific artworks and discuss a range of key terms and
concepts. Covering major international artistic movements, from Impressionism
to Pop art and beyond, we will consider how, since the industrial
revolution, artists such as J.M.W Turner, Edouard Manet, Piet
Mondrian, Mark Rothko, Bridget Riley, Gerhard Richter, and Amy
Sillman, have examined the conditions of contemporary existence through
the experience of sight, as structured in and by painting. Exploring shifts in
the production and reception of art, the role of the artist, issues of
materiality and perception, the relationship between abstraction and
representation, and the politics of looking, this course aims to equip students
with a set of critical tools with which to approach visual objects and shape an
understanding of the historical concerns surrounding them.</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

})();

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">HART1701</h1>
<p class="p">This
ten week course will introduce students to the architecture of medieval London.
We will analyse, <em>in situ</em>, some of its
foremost surviving examples—such as the Tower of London, Great St Bart’s,
Temple Church and Westminster Abbey—before locating them within the larger
contexts of post-Conquest England and current scholarship. We will look at the
ways in which a variety of both ecclesiastical and secular buildings were
constructed, the ends to which they were commissioned, and (where possible)
evidence for how they were received. </p>
<p class="p"> One of the twentieth
century’s greatest architectural clichés reads that “form follows function”. In
addition to the above, one of the primary aims of this course will also be to
challenge any such assumptions. If medieval buildings
do sometimes express their function(s) by how they look, then they very
often also acted as deep repositories—then as now—for a much broader range of
socio-political, cultural and theological capital. Despite appearances, they
are neither static nor unchanging. Rather than
ever-following, they can perhaps be more accurately described as
ever-negotiating or ever-<em>becoming</em>
part of the landscape of the city. </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">

            //set conditional assets for main.js
            var globalSiteSpecificVars = {
                pathToJquery: '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-1.9.1.min'
                ,googleAnalyticsIdsArray: ['UA-52716039-2']//specify array of site specific id's NOT UCL generic UA-943297-1
            }
            if(cuttingTheMustard){
                globalSiteSpecificVars.pathToJquery = '//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/jquery-2.1.1.min';
            }
        </script> 

        <script src="//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/indigo/js/lib/require.min.js"></script>
        <script src='//cdn.ucl.ac.uk/skins/UCLIndigoSkin/default-theme/main.js'></script>
        <script>require(['app/general','theme/indigo-autocomplete-ga','theme/silva','app/searchWithAutoComplete','app/lightbox',]);//load the default stuff</script>

        <script>
(function(){
  if (window.BOOMR && window.BOOMR.version) { return; }
  var dom,doc,where,iframe = document.createElement("iframe"),win = window;

  function boomerangSaveLoadTime(e) {
    win.BOOMR_onload=(e && e.timeStamp) || new Date().getTime();
  }
  if (win.addEventListener) {
    win.addEventListener("load", boomerangSaveLoadTime, false);
  } else if (win.attachEvent) {
    win.attachEvent("onload", boomerangSaveLoadTime);
  }

  iframe.src = "javascript:void(0)";
  iframe.title = ""; iframe.role = "presentation";
  (iframe.frameElement || iframe).style.cssText = "width:0;height:0;border:0;display:none;";
  where = document.getElementsByTagName("script")[0];
  where.parentNode.insertBefore(iframe, where);

  try {
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  } catch(e) {
    dom = document.domain;
    iframe.src="javascript:var d=document.open();d.domain='"+dom+"';void(0);";
    doc = iframe.contentWindow.document;
  }
  doc.open()._l = function() {
    var js = this.createElement("script");
    if (dom) { this.domain = dom; }
    js.id = "boomr-if-as";
    js.src = "//c.go-mpulse.net/boomerang/" +
    "SUWW2-HAKPB-Q4WN7-TQ6VL-GTMT2";
    BOOMR_lstart=new Date().getTime();
    this.body.appendChild(js);
  };
  doc.write('<body onload="document._l();">');
  doc.close();
})();
</script>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">HART1702</h1>
<p class="p"><br /> This
course presents London as an architectural microcosm of the State. Through an
overview of key historical moments and an examination of several public and
ecclesiastical buildings, it will present London as a city in which public
architecture was consciously and deliberately utilised and propagandized as a
potent device through which the essential values of and core political vision
for the State was communicated to its citizens, the wider British population
and to the foreign eye. It will consider the means by which several key
building projects were mediated and politicised, thereby being imbued with
socio-political significance both to contemporary audiences and later
architectural historians. </p>
<p class="p"> Given
the long period covered by this course, it is not intended to be a
comprehensive survey of London’s public architecture, but rather a selective
case-study examination of a number of architectural projects from which wider
issues of meaning can be discussed. In doing so, it will consider the contested
means through which later architectural historians have attempted to ascribe
meaning to the built environment and the relative value of such
interpretational tools.</p>
<p class="p"> It
will focus on several key moments in the history of the city during which
public architecture was consciously utilised as a means of mediating the core
values of the State including the establishment of the Stuart dynasty; the
rebuilding of the City in the wake of the great fire of 1666; the Glorious
Revolution and Hanoverian settlement; the industrial revolution; the rise of
the British Empire; and the architectural response to destruction and societal
upheaval in the wake of the Second World War. The course, taught primarily
through onsite visits, is structured chronologically and thematically. </p>
<p class="p"> Providing a first-hand
introduction to the varied public architecture of London across a wide
chronological spectrum, the course aims to consider the capital’s architects as
responsive to financial, political, societal and cultural shifts and to
deliberate the various means by which architectural historians translate and
ascribe meaning to those architectural responses. In doing so it will provide a
sound knowledge of the development of London’s public architecture contextualised
within contemporary socio-political and religious <em>milieux</em> and will encourage a critical approach to the work of later
architectural historians. <sub> </sub></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <!--noindex-->

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">HART1703</h1>
<p class="p">This
course looks at how architects and designers have transformed London in the
past century. Beginning with a visit to the Architecture Gallery at the
Victoria &amp; Albert Museum, we will discuss iconic buildings of 20th-century
London through a series of site-based classes. We will explore the theme of
‘modernisms’ in visits to private dwellings by the international architects
Wells Coates (Lawn Road Flats, 1933) and Ernö Goldfinger (2 Willow Road, 1939)
and as well as key public modernist buildings in and around Bloomsbury, the
RIBA headquarters at 66 Portland Place (1933) and The Royal College of Physicians
(1960s). We will also look at modernist schemes of social regeneration, such as
the radical Finsbury Health Centre (1938) and later the Spa Green and Bevin
Court estates. The opportunities to rebuild London after the Second World War
will form the core of second part of the course, in tours to the Royal Festival
Hall and the South Bank compound, as well as landmark housing projects from the
1960s-1970s, the Barbican, Balfron Tower and Robin Hood Garden estates. The
course will conclude with visits to Canary Wharf as an example of urban
regeneration in the 1980s Docklands, and to King’s Cross, looking towards
post-modern developments in urban planning and architecture in London. The aim
of the course is to introduce students the history and theory of architecture
and equip them with critical and analytical skills to examine and discuss the
built environment of the past century. Students may be asked to undertake
presentations and choose case-studies to further develop their skills. </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>

            <!--endnoindex-->
            <div class="site-content__inner clearfix">
                <div class="site-content__body">
                    <!--noindex-->
                    
    <nav class="breadcrumb clearfix">
        <ul class="breadcrumb__list">
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk">UCL Home</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history">History of Art</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>

                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students">Prospective Students</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->

                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/art-london"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/art-london">Art in London Courses</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/art-london/hart1704"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/art-london/hart1704">HART1704</a>
                
            </li>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">HART1704</h1>
<p class="p"> This course
explores some of London’s most iconic twentieth-century architecture. Following
a journey through London since the First World War, the course is organised
around weekly visits to selected buildings, galleries and museum collections.
In this way, the module will trace the roots, development and debates of the
modern architecture movement in London.</p>
<p class="p"> Weekly site
visits will include: the architecture gallery of the Victoria and Albert Museum,
the headquarters of the Royal Institute of British Architects, the London Zoo
at Regent’s Park, the City of London and the South Bank, the Olympic area will
be explored, and the avant-garde art and architecture of Pick and Holden’s
London Underground.</p>
<p class="p"> The course
will conclude with a walking tour of King’s Cross Station and its surrounding
area, as a way of investigating how architecture in London moved into the
‘post-modern’ era.</p>
<p class="p"> By the end of the course students will have
gained a general knowledge of architecture in London during this period, and a
wider historical understanding of how the buildings and sites investigated each
week have been produced and interpreted. Students will acquire the capacity to discuss
critically the contribution of such buildings towards the transformation of the
city. They will be familiar with key architectural and cultural theories
relating to the city from the fields of art history and urban studies, and will
be able to apply their acquired analytical skills to discuss critically buildings
and urban projects from this period.</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />

    <nav class="breadcrumb clearfix">
        <ul class="breadcrumb__list">
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk"
                   data-href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk">UCL Home</a>
                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->

                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history"

                <!--[if lte IE 7]>&raquo;<![endif]-->
            </li>
            <li class="breadcrumb__item">
                <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/art-london/hart1705"

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">HART1705</h1>
<p class="p"><br /> This course explores some of London's most iconic architecture
from the second half of the Twentieth Century until the present. Throughout the
course we will visit a series of buildings and examine the historical context
and theory produced around them. The task is to produce a critical analysis of
each through the study of their formal style, the organisation of spaces and
the relation with their urban environment. </p>
<p class="p"> We will start with an
introductory seminar on the history of London over the aforementioned timeframe
that will provide us with an overarching understanding of the context. We will
then initiate our building-based classes by visiting the Aviary at London Zoo
by the prominent architect Cedric Price, whose innovative &quot;mega-structures&quot;
influenced a whole generation of architects. In this visit, we will discuss the
legacy of the Modernist movement and its ideas to foster social innovation and
change. We will then go on to examine the Brutalist architecture in London by
visiting the National Theatre and the Barbican Estate. We will finish our
exploration of Modernist architecture with a visit to the Robin Hood Gardens, a
housing estate project by the Smithsons that represents the Modernist
rationalist utopia of a society with decent houses for everybody. From there,
we will move on to briefly review the Post-Modernism movement and its &quot;high-tech architecture&quot; in the visits to the Lloyd’s Building by Richard Rogers,
and Canary Wharf station by Norman Foster. We will continue with a visit to the
Millennium Dome, representative of the &quot;Architecture for the New Millennium&quot;.
We will end our journey with the Olympic Park.</p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">HART1706</h1>
<p class="p"> This course looks at the architecture of nineteenth
and twentieth-century London from a social and political angle.
Starting with the influence of imperialism in the mid-nineteenth century
and ending with gentrification in London today, we will examine how
political change shapes the city. The course will progress
chronologically, addressing different building types and the work of different
architects and groups, including Tecton and the Camden Borough
Architects Department. We will visit and discuss well-known buildings
such as the Royal Festival Hall and the Victoria and Albert Museum, but we
will also consider housing projects and architecture that is
often overlooked: structures of incarceration and disciplinary power,
such as Holloway and Pentonville Prisons, and the infrastructures
that keep the city functioning. In doing so, we will explore the changing
roles of the state, private companies and architects in designing the
city and consider for whom these architectures are conceived and
built.  </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>
                     
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
        <!--noindex-->

                <li class="footer__item"><a href="//www.thebloomsbury.com/">UCL Bloomsbury Theatre</a></li>
            </ul>
        </article>

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 


<h2 class="heading">BA Courses 2017/18</h2>





<p class="p"> <strong>Courses offered to UCL History of Art BA, History of Art with Material Studies BA and Affiliate/Erasmus students registered with the UCL 
Department of History of Art.</strong></p>
<p class="p">ALL Year 1 Thematic Seminars, Year 2 Period Courses, Year 2 Methods Courses, and
Year 3 Special Subjects are restricted to History of Art Students only (SH, CH,
BASc/Culture).</p>

<h2 class="heading">Year 1</h2>











<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART1001 History of Art and its Objects - The Core Course</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/natasha-eaton">Natasha Eaton</a><strong><br />Timetabled:</strong> Autumn and Spring Terms; Fridays 2-5pm.<br />This
 is an obligatory introductory course for all History of Art students 
and is not normally available to students from outside the department. 
The course is an introduction to a range of skills required to study the
 History of Art, including the first-hand study of works of art. It is 
designed to familiarise students with some current debates in the 
subject, and introduce them to a variety of theoretical positions of 
which they need to be aware in the course of their degree. <br /><strong>Student Contact Hours: </strong>40, in 20 weekly 1-hour lectures and 20 1-hour seminars.<strong><br />Duration of Course:</strong> 20+ weeks, beginning in first week of Autumn term.<strong><br />Student Workload: </strong>Reading and other preparation for weekly classes, three pieces of written work and an oral presentation (notes submitted).<strong><br /></strong><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong> 3 assessed essays (1500-2000 words each) and 1 oral/presentation task (each element 25% of the overall mark)<strong>.</strong><br /><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Students should normally be in the first year of a Single or Combined Honours degree in History of Art.</p>
<p class="p"> <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/first-year" target="_self">First Year Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART1306 History of European Art: Classical to Renaissance - The Foundation Course I - 0.5 cu (Autumn)</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutors:<a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/allison-stielau" target="_self"> Allison
Stielau</a><strong><br />Timetabled:</strong> Autumn Term; Wednesdays, 9-11am.<br />These
 are obligatory introductory courses for all History of Art students. In ten
 lectures each term students are introduced to the dominant narrative of
 art history as an historical development ('the canon'), and are 
encouraged to look at that model critically. The subject matter of the 
lecture series ranges from classical to contemporary art. Space is also 
given to categories outside the conventional canon.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours: </strong>Lectures and question time: 20 hours for each course.<br /> <strong>Duration of  Course:</strong> 10+ weeks, the first course begins in first week of Autumn term, the second in the first week of the Spring term.<br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong> Attendance at all lectures, reading in support of lectures, exam.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong> 100% by unseen examination in Summer Term.<br /><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Students should normally be in the first year of a Single or Combined Honours degree in History of Art.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/first-year" target="_self">First Year Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART1303 Science for Art Historians - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"><strong>Course tutor: </strong><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/emma-richardson">Emma Richardson</a><br /><strong>Timetabled:</strong> Autumn Term; Tuesdays 2-4pm.<br />Introductory course
covering basic organic and in-organic chemistry in lab-based environment for
first year History of Art students. The course will lay a scientific foundation
for understanding the relationship between the composition of artefacts, physical
properties, and application. The first part of the course will cover topics
such as the periodic table, solubility, pH, and bonding. We will begin with a
review of basic organic and inorganic chemistry, to set up a deeper
understanding of the issues surrounding materials, such as the deterioration
mechanisms of works of art.<br /><strong>        Duration of course: </strong>10 weeks, beginning in the first week of the Spring term.<strong><br />Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />Student Workload: </strong>Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, lab work, essay<br /><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong> 20% written-up lab work, 20% essay (c. 2000 words), 60% by unseen exam (2 hours).<br /> <strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Normally only offered to 1st-year HAMS students. No previous experience of chemistry is required to undertake this course.<br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART1304 Thematic Seminar - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Overall course tutor: t.b.c.<strong><br />Timetabled:</strong> Autumn Term: Thursdays 11am-1pm.<br />This
 course is designed specifically for students on the first-year Single 
Honours History of Art, or History of Art with Material Studies programmes. It comprises a 
number of historical and topical seminar options, which are designed to provide students with smaller group teaching and
direct engagement with art objects in museums, galleries and historical sites.
Students take one out of the several options on offer during the academic year.
The course is taught as a mixture of informal lectures, seminars and/or gallery
visits, accompanied by weekly reading projects and group discussion of key
issues. <br /><strong>Duration of Course:</strong> 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong> Attendance at all classes, back-up reading, 2 essays.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong>
 Two essays, one
1500-2000 words weighted at 40% submitted before Reading Week, the other
 2500-3000 words weighted at 60% submitted by the end of term.<strong><br />Prerequisites:</strong> Appropriate background in history or art history. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART1305: History of European Art: Renaissance to Contemporary - The Foundation Course II - 0.5 cu (Spring)</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutors: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/rose-marie-san-juan">Rose Marie San Juan</a><strong><br />Timetabled:</strong> HART1305 Spring Term; Wednesdays, 9-11am.<br />These
 are obligatory introductory courses for all History of Art students. In ten
 lectures each term students are introduced to the dominant narrative of
 art history as an historical development ('the canon'), and are 
encouraged to look at that model critically. The subject matter of the 
lecture series ranges from classical to contemporary art. Space is also 
given to categories outside the conventional canon.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours: </strong>Lectures and question time: 20 hours for each course.<br /> <strong>Duration of  Course:</strong> 10+ weeks, the first course begins in first week of Autumn term, the second in the first week of the Spring term.<br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong> Attendance at all lectures, reading in support of lectures, exam.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong> 100% by unseen examination in Summer Term.<br /><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Students should normally be in the first year of a Single or Combined Honours degree in History of Art.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/first-year" target="_self">First Year Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART1302 Methods and Materials I - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">  Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/hanna-hoelling">Hanna Hölling</a><strong><br />Timetabled:</strong> Spring Term; Tuesdays 2-4pm.<br />This course addresses methods and materials of the artist with a particular emphasis
on artistic practices deployed in the second half of the twentieth century. In
the context of the history of artistic techniques and technologies used in fine
arts, students will have the opportunity to discuss the physical constitution
of artworks alongside their concept and materiality. Among the issues addressed
will be the so-called time-based media (film, video, television), and
software-based art (installation, kinetic sculptures, earthworks,
biodegradables, and performance). What exactly constitutes an artwork? How does
the work endure over time? How does reproducibility, iteration, degradability
and obsolescence affect what the work is and what it may become?</p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Duration of Course:</strong> 10 weeks, beginning in 1st week of Autumn term.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong>
 Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, practical 
work, one short written task, possibly one short presentation, and one 
assessed essay.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong> 40% by course-essay (c. 2000 words), 60% by unseen exam (2 hours).<br /><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Normally only offered to 1st-year HAMS students.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART1307 Thematic Seminar - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Overall Course tutor: t.b.c.<strong><br />Timetabled:</strong> Spring Term: Thursdays 11am-1pm.<br />This
 course is designed specifically for students on the first-year
Single Honours History of Art, or History of Art with Material Studies programmes. It 
comprises a number of historical and topical seminar options, which are designed
to provide students with smaller group teaching and direct engagement with art
objects in museums, galleries and historical sites. Students take one out of
the several options on offer during the academic year. The course is taught as
a mixture of informal lectures, seminars and/or gallery visits, accompanied by
weekly reading projects and group discussion of key issues.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:</strong> 10 weeks.<br /> <strong>Student Workload:</strong> Attendance at all classes, back-up reading, 2 essays.<br /> <strong>Means of Assessment:</strong>
 Two essays, one
1500-2000 words weighted at 40% submitted before Reading Week, the other
 2500-3000 words weighted at 60% submitted by the end of term.<strong><br />Prerequisites:</strong> Appropriate background in history or art history. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
</dl>
 

</div>


<hr class="rule" />

<h2 class="heading">Year 2</h2>





<p class="p"><strong>All courses are 0.5 unit courses taught in one term. Note that the courses are arranged
 with the autumn term options followed by the spring term options</strong></p>



<h4 class="heading">Autumn Term:
</h4>









<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2002 Methodologies of Art History - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutors: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/robert-mills" target="_self">Robert Mills</a> and <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/stephanie-schwartz" target="_self">Stephanie Schwartz</a><br /> <strong>Timetabled</strong>: Autumn Term: Tuesdays 11am-1pm.<br />This
text-based course introduces students to a variety of different
methodologies and approaches current in the discipline. Through
lectures, seminars and weekly reading tasks students learn to identify
and evaluate different kinds of art historical writing. Topics
addressed normally include: formalist positions in modernist criticism,
iconography, the social history of art, theories of ideology,
semiotics, discourse theory, psycho-analytic approaches, issues of
gender, sexuality and subjectivity, post-colonial theory and race and
ethnicity.<strong><br />Duration of course: </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />Student Contact Hours: </strong>20 hours, a mixture of lectures and text-based discussion classes.<strong><br />Student Workload: </strong>Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<strong><br />Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
 essays: a short Response Paper (c. 1500 words due around Reading Week 
weighted at 40%); a second essay (2000-2500 words due the last day of 
class weighted at 60%).</p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Normally only offered to 2nd-year History of Art students. Other closely similar experience might be acceptable.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2002">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2011 Advanced Lecture in the History of Art: Histories of Photography - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/stephanie-schwartz" target="_self">Stephanie Schwartz</a><strong><br />Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Mondays 2-4pm.<br />
This
course surveys the history of photography from its invention in the 1830s to
its postmodern iterations in the 1970s. More specifically, it considers several
key episodes in photography’s history through discussions of the contentious
and public debates about the ways in which photography has been historicized.
Is photography an art? Is it—was it—a threat to art? Is photography something
closer to a tool or technology? Is it media? Throughout the course we will
consider the myriad ways in which these questions have been posed and pondered
by poets, critics, scientists, photographers and art historians.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Duration of Course:</strong>
 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student contact hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student 
Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, one essay, and exam.<br /><strong>Means of
 assessment: </strong>50% by essay (2000-2500 words), 50% by unseen 2 hour examination.<br /><strong>Prerequisites:

 </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art History programme 
or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2108 Modern and Contemporary Art: The Anti-Aesthetic - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Rye Holmboe<strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Wednesdays 11am-1pm.<br />
This course considers thematic categories that have
come to be associated with the anti-aesthetic: the abject, the carnivalesque,
the grotesque, the primal and the formless, among others, and thinks about the
ways in which these categories have been mobilised in modern and contemporary
art. Areas considered are, for example, the theoretical writings of Georges
Bataille; the question of the Dionysiac in the performances of the Viennese
Actionists; and the mobilisation of the body in 1960s performance art. Later
parts of the course will think about how the anti-aesthetic might be understood
in the context of the art institution and in its relationship to
commodification and the art market. This interdisciplinary course, which
considers examples from painting, sculpture, performance and theatre, explores
the extent to which anti-aesthetic categories can be seen to be transgressive,
asking what the critical and political stakes of this category might be today.<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours<strong>.<br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2202 London and Paris, c. 1700-1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff" target="_self">Susannah Walker<strong> </strong></a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Fridays 2-4pm.<br />
The course deals with the development of London and Paris as sites of 
visual fascination through their architecture, sculpture and the 
emergence of the public art exhibition alongside alternative sites of 
urban spectacle including: the theatrical performances,  public 
executions, military parades and spaces of consumption. <br />The course 
will consider mediation of London and Paris through literature, costume,
 print culture and cartography. Material will be viewed through the 
conceptual frameworks of the spectacle, &quot;modernity&quot;, the city as 
politically contested space, the official urban plan and its 
&quot;underworlds&quot;, the commodity fetish and the translation of alternative 
sensory approaches to the city (scent/ touch/ sound) to its visual 
image.<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, and 3 
perambulations around London).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2202" target="_self">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2213 Representing 'Others' c. 1700-c. 1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">  
Course tutor:<strong> </strong><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/natasha-eaton">Natasha Eaton</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Thursdays 2-4pm.<br />For the last 30 years, ‘otherness’, ‘alterity’ ‘empire’ and
postcoloniality are central to how we engage with the world. From debates
surrounding globalization, to the ways in which we are rethinking Britishness,
imperialism and its troubled legacies continue to occupy our political
landscape and to inform the entanglements of British and non-western
art. As leading anthropologist Nicholas B. Dirks warns, ‘in calling for the
study of the aesthetics of colonialism, we might end up aestheticising
colonialism, producing a radical chic version of Raj nostalgia’. With this
cautionary agenda in mind, the aim of the course is to problematise the
aesthetic and political underpinnings of these cultural encounters. Key
issues will involve images in magic and worship, the development of
Orientalism, primitivism, the role of art-as-gift, the breakdown of
realism/mimesis in the colony, the ‘translation’ of native objects into art by
the European ‘museum effect’ and the adaptation or transmutation of British
pictures by the colonised. Resistance, mimicry, hybridity and alternative
strategies for cultural exchange, will be read through post-colonial theory in
conjunction with, or against the grain of visual materials, so as to contest
art history’s ‘hegemony’ over the image-making of other places.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2214 Architecture and Modernity - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   
Course tutor: Jacob Paskins<strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Fridays 11am-1pm.<br />
Architecture today is
dominated by international design firms that produce spectacular buildings
across the world. But how did architecture become global? This course asks how
architectural knowledge and styles spread across continents during the past 150
years. We will confront how European colonialism exported architecture and
urban planning to North Africa, the Middle East and India. How did the striking
architecture of universal expositions transmit ideas about modernity? How did
the so-called International Style of modernism spread through Europe, the
United States, Japan, China and South America? Guided by the work of
postcolonial theorists and historians, we will examine the reactions to an
apparently global form of modern architecture in the twentieth century.
Ultimately, we ask if there is any room for regional difference in globalised
architectural production? <strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2217 Theory and History of Conservation - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course
 tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/hanna-hoelling">Hanna Hölling</a><strong><br />Timetabled</strong>: Autumn Term; Tuesdays 2-4pm. <br />When thinking about artworks and artefacts,
conservation provides an extensively rich area of study of their modes of
conception, creation, dissemination, display and perpetuation. This is due to
the premise that in order to engage with an artwork, conservation first and
foremost seeks to understand what the work is and how it functions within and
beyond its historic moment. Outsiders often refer to conservation as a
homogenous field of activity that aims at prolonging the cultural
objects’ lives into the future. But there are, in fact, different conservations that
operate with respect to diverse theories, types of artefacts,
institutional settings, historic contexts, and the cultures that produce
them. During this course, we will sketch a picture of
conservation that always exists between a set of dichotomies of hands and
minds, practice and theory, the tangible and the intangible, and the
traditional and the new. By putting today’s conservation into an historical
perspective, we will examine how more recent conservation became of necessity a
reflective, critical practice. Visits to museums and sites of conservation and
special tasks will enrich classroom discussions.<br /><strong>Duration 
of Course:</strong> 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student
 Workload:</strong> Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong> 2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<br /><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Students should 
have completed a first-year Art History programme or have equivalent 
relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2217">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2238 (HAMS only) Methods and Materials II - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/emma-richardson">Emma Richardson</a><strong><br />Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Mondays 11am-1pm.<br />
 This course will expand on, and extend, the materials and methodologies
 covered during the first year’s course, presenting an overview of the 
major classes of materials found within museum collections, and 
addressing their application as artist’s materials. In this second 
course, focus will be given to the more obscure materials found in works
 of art, for example wax, synthetic resins, and foam. Discussion will be
 given to the types of physical properties that different materials 
exhibit, so that the student might begin to understand why an artist may
 have used a certain material.<br />
This course will provide the student with the theoretical and practical 
aspects of artists' techniques and application, and highlight some of 
the issues surrounding their preservation and conservation.<br /> <strong>Duration of Course:</strong>
 10 weeks.<br /> <strong>Student contact hours:</strong> 20+ hours in 10 weekly 2-hour classes, plus supervised lab/project work.<br /> <strong>Student 
Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, preparation for classes, independent project work.<br /> <strong>Means of
 assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<br /> <strong>Prerequisites:

 </strong>Students should have completed the first-year Art History programme 
or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2238" target="_self">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
</dl>
 

</div>


<hr class="rule" />



<h4 class="heading">Spring Term:</h4>









<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2001 History of the Category Art - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/mechthild-fend">Mechthild Fend</a><strong> </strong>and t.b.c.<strong><br />Timetabled</strong>: Spring; Tuesdays 11am-1pm.<br />This course aims to familiarise students with the ways in
which the concept of art has evolved in Europe. It examines the emergence of
Aesthetics as a distinct branch of philosophy in eighteenth-century in Britain,
France and Germany, and will consider subsequent nineteenth-century
developments especially in relation to the role of the category Art in
Modernism, and the ways in which it has informed more recent philosophies and
histories of art. It is based on the study of texts in Seminars.<br /><strong> Duration of course:</strong> 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours:</strong> 20 hours, a mixture of lectures and text-based discussion classes. <br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong> Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<strong><br />Means of Assessment</strong>:
 Two essays: a short Response Paper (1350-1500 words due around Reading 
Week weighted at 40%); a second essay (2000-2500 words due the last day 
of class weighted at 60%).<br /><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Normally only offered to 2nd-year History of Art students. Other closely similar experience might be acceptable.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2001">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2005 Methodologies of Making - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/hanna-hoelling">Hannah
Hölling</a><br /> <strong>Timetabled</strong>: Spring Term; Thursday 4-6pm.<br />
This course introduces the discursive frameworks of
art production and making, remaking, collecting, mediating and conserving. It
encompasses readings and discussions centred around theories related to the
materiality and the immaterial, makers and their tools, the workings of
collections, including questions of conservation, and the notions of time and
archive. For the most part, classes will begin with a lecture followed by a
discussion. In the first part of the class, students will be introduced to
theoretical underpinnings and case studies related to the main topic of
the class. During the second part, students will try to apply these
theories to one exemplary case study of art production, curating or
conservation across the centuries. How is theory performed? How is it entangled
with practice? How can we theorise practice or develop a practical aesthetic?<strong><br />Duration of course</strong><strong>: </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />Student Workload: </strong>Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Means of Assessment</strong>: Two
 essays: a short Response Paper (c. 1500 words due towards the end of 
term weighted at 40%); a second essay (2000-2500 words due at the 
beginning of the Exam term weighted at 60%).<br /><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Normally only offered to 2nd-year History of Art students. Other closely similar experience might be acceptable.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2005">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2010 Advanced Lecture in the History of Art: Early Modern Bodies - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutor: Rosemary Moore<br /><strong>Timetabled: </strong>Spring term; Mondays 2-4pm.<br />The body was at the
centre of artistic, religious and ‘scientific’ concerns throughout the period
1500–1700. These included, for example: the religious and political
controversies of the Reformation and Counter Reformation, which raised
questions over the relationship between body and image, sensation and the
sacred; the development of perspectival techniques, including anamorphosis,
which requires one to adjust the position of one’s own body in relation to the
painted image; the renewed interest in mythology and anatomy; as well as
encounters between Europeans and the peoples of the Americas. This lecture
course will engage with a range of artworks, from watercolours, frescoes and
paintings on canvas, to drawings, prints and sculpture. Case studies will include
works by well-known and celebrated artists such as Raphael, Dürer and Titian,
in addition to images that students may be less familiar with, for example
woodcuts from medical treatises or books of marvels and ‘monsters’. Today, just
as in the early modern period, the body continues to be a locus of heated
debate concerning identity, gender, race, sexuality and eroticism. Readings
will therefore encompass a wide variety of theoretical approaches to the body.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:</strong>
 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student
 Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, one essay and exam.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment: </strong>50% by essay (2000-2500 words), 50% by unseen
 2 hour examination.<strong><br />Prerequisites: </strong>Students should have 
completed a first-year Art History programme or have equivalent relevant
 experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2202 London and Paris, c. 1700-1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff" target="_self">Susannah Walker<strong> </strong></a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Fridays 2-4pm.<br />
The course deals with the development of London and Paris as sites of 
visual fascination through their architecture, sculpture and the 
emergence of the public art exhibition alongside alternative sites of 
urban spectacle including: the theatrical performances,  public 
executions, military parades and spaces of consumption. <br />The course 
will consider mediation of London and Paris through literature, costume,
 print culture and cartography. Material will be viewed through the 
conceptual frameworks of the spectacle, &quot;modernity&quot;, the city as 
politically contested space, the official urban plan and its 
&quot;underworlds&quot;, the commodity fetish and the translation of alternative 
sensory approaches to the city (scent/ touch/ sound) to its visual 
image.<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, and 3 
perambulations around London).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2202" target="_self">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2206 Modernism and the European Avant-Gardes - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Maria Mileeva<strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Thursdays 2-4pm.<br />This course will examine the history, theory and practice of
International Constructivism. Chronologically positioned in the interwar
period, the development of Constructivism will be discussed in relation to
examples of art, architecture, and design. The start of the course will locate
the origins of Constructivism in the social and political context of the
October Revolution in Russia and the radical artistic experiments in Paris,
Moscow, and Munich before the outbreak of the First World War. Outlining key
themes and interrelationships - such as utopia and revolution, artistic
experiment and mass culture - this course will relate artistic production of
the European avant-garde to the demands of politics and cultural experiment in
the turbulent period of 1920s and 1930s. The second half of the course will
address the international imperatives of Dada, Constructivism and the Bauhaus
by looking at a series of artistic and theoretical developments in Germany,
France, Poland, Hungary, and Britain. We will examine the art and writings of
Aleksandr Rodchenko, El Lissitzky, Naum Gabo, László Moholy-Nagy, Theo van
Doesburg, Kurt Schwitters, Hans Richter and Walter Gropius. The course will
critically discuss and examine the discourses of the terms modernism, avant-garde
and abstraction in their application to the theory and practice of
constructivism.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2215 Image/Object: Modernism and After - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">  
Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/briony-fer">Briony Fer</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Tuesdays 2-4pm.<br />
Course covering pivotal moments
within twentieth-century art, from the crisis of representation that triggered
the formation of the historical avant-gardes in the 1910s and 20s through to
notions of what art can look like after conceptualism that continue to shape
art practice now<strong>.<br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, including a Gallery Visit).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2229 Gender and Representation in France, c.1750–1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/mechthild-fend">Mechthild Fend</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Wednesdays 11am-1pm.<br />From old regime Monarchy via the French Revolution
and the Napoleonic Empire to the Restauration the hundred years between ca 1750
and 1850 constitute not only an era of tremendous political change but also a
period in which notions of gender and sexuality, and indeed the lives of men
and women were in flux. This course explores how the visual arts engaged with
these changes and how they took part in the shaping of new ideals of
masculinity and femininity. It considers furthermore the gendering of social
categories such as public and private space, or artistic categories such as the
Rococo style, the nude as a genre, or professional art making itself. Looking
in particular at painting, the course will focus on works by artist such as
Boucher, Greuze, David, Girodet, Ingres, Gericault, and Delacroix<strong>.<br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2237 Relics, Saints, Images and Power - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/robert-mills" target="_self">Robert Mills</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Fridays 11am-1pm.<br />
Saints were the celebrities of
medieval Europe. From the miracles they worked to the rituals and journeys they
inspired, holy bodies were invested with immense spiritual and political power.
Relics were also hugely important as a source of aesthetic inspiration. This
course explores art and architecture associated with physical remains of
saints. Focusing especially on three cult sites in the Middle Ages – Jerusalem,
Santiago de Compostela and Canterbury – we will see how imagery associated with
saintly bodies adapts and morphs to suit the needs of different times and
places. Looking at this imagery through the prism of categories such as
translation, liminality, the simulacrum and the souvenir, the course asks how modern
critical frameworks can reconnect us with the potency of the relic. As well as
considering reliquaries and cult statues, we will explore such phenomena as mappaemundi or world maps, virtual or
armchair pilgrimage, and replica buildings designed to ‘translate’ sites
associated with the Holy Land from East to West. At the end of the course we
will also consider the afterlife of the relic. Why, in some parts of Europe,
did the power of saintly remains seemingly diminish? Where and how has it
re-emerged?<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, including a Gallery Visit).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience. <br /></p>

<h2 class="heading"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2237" target="_self">Summer reading list</a></h2>






</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2239 (HAMS only) The Development and Application of Textiles in Works of Art and Artefacts - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course Tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/emma-richardson">Emma Richardson</a><strong><br />Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term: Mondays 11am-1pm.<br />
This course will combine both
theoretical and practical approaches to the understanding of textiles, their
properties and their application as artistic media. By examining the history
and development of textile, we will begin to map their usage through the
centuries to the present day, and their application within art and design. We
will explore the physical properties of fibres, yarns and textiles, investigate
the implications for fabrication, and understand what impact this has on their
visual nature. In addition to seminars and lectures, the course will include
guest speakers, and object based learning at the Victoria and Albert Museum and
The National Gallery. Additionally, practical sessions, where the student will
study the structure of fibres under the microscope, as well as extrude
synthetic fibres, will provide an appreciation for materiality and help
interpret textile artworks of various construction.<strong><br />Duration of Course:</strong> 10 weeks.<strong><br />Student
 Contact Hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and 
back-up reading, private gallery visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />Means of 
Assessment:</strong> 2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />Prerequisites:</strong>
 Students should have completed a first-year Art History programme or 
have equivalent relevant academic experience. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2242 Sense and Sensation in Early Modern Art - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor:<strong> </strong><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/allison-stielau">Allison Stielau</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Tuesdays 4-6pm.<br />Early modern art was experienced not simply
through the eyes, but also through the full range of human sense perception.
This course considers the complex web of sight, smell, touch, taste,
and sound within which artworks were embedded and out of which spectacles—like
banquets and triumphal entries—were created. Although material will be drawn
from across the continent, a particular focus rests on northern Europe in the
period 1400 to 1600. Sites for exploration of sense-experience include the
court, the street, the kitchen, the artist’s workshop, and the anatomy theatre.
The role of the senses in late medieval piety and the rejection of sensuous
worship by Protestant Reformers constitutes a significant unit of the course.
Visits to local collections and films of historical reenactment offer
opportunities for close-looking, analysis, and critique.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
