<hr class="rule" />
<p class="p"><strong>FINAL YEAR SPECIAL SUBJECT COURSES</strong></p>






<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3101 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: Popular and Political Cultures in Nineteenth-Century England  - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/susannah-walker">Susannah Walker</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Tuesdays 2-4pm.<br />
The
‘popular cultures’ of nineteenth-century England can feel
somewhat familiar in the image saturated present. We may find
contemporary parallels to this period's sensationalist news stories,
popular songs, flags, tattoos, religious
prints, astrological imagery, panoramas, fairs and shows. However, ‘popular
culture’ is a complex and contested term. A search for authentic culture ‘of
the people’ and debates over who controls it and who is excluded from
it remain politically charged.<br />
This
course will analyse the cultural worlds inhabited by early nineteenth
century publics using a range of theories of mass media and popular
culture. We will make close, object based studies of James
Gillray, William Blake, Thomas Bewick, George Cruikshank, J.M.W. Turner
and John Martin, considering the intersections between their artistic
ideas and the popular cultures around them.<br />
The final part of the course will look at the
challenges and possibilities of curating and communicating
nineteenth-century popular culture, making close studies of its place
in galleries and museums. Part of the assessment will
entail designing a Public Engagement project based on course
content. It is therefore a particularly suitable option for those seeking
careers in galleries or arts education.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3102 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: Russian Art and Culture: Realism and Avant-Garde - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Maria Mileeva<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Mondays 4-6pm.<br />
This course will examine
conflicts and developments in Russian and Soviet visual culture, from the turn
of the century, through the October Revolution and to the death of Stalin in
1953. Focusing on the complex relationship between art and politics during this
tumultuous period of war, revolution and social change, the course examines
aspects of rupture and continuity in the development of Russian cultural
identity. We will investigate Russian twentieth-century artists in active
dialogue with artistic developments in Europe and America, discussing case
studies of travel, exhibition, official export and emigration. We will study
Russian art both inside and outside of Russia, as its makers and commentators
crossed cultural and geographical borders making contact with artistic
developments in Paris, Berlin, Munich, and New York.<br />
The course will follow broad changes in Russian
painting, graphic art, architecture, film and design, alongside artistic
movements such as Symbolism, Primitivism, Cubofuturism, Constructivism,
Suprematism and Socialist Realism. We will consider competing and often
contradictory desires amongst artists and critics to construct a national
artistic language based on the traditions of Russian folk and icon painting,
whilst embracing aesthetic and theoretical experiments drawn from the European
avant-garde. Specific artists under investigation will include Wassily
Kandinsky, Mikhail Larionov, Natalia Goncharova, Kazimir Malevich, and El
Lissitzky, amongst others.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3103 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: The Italian Avant-Garde - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/pgt-research-students/flavia-frigeri">Flavia Frigeri</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Tuesdays 4-6pm.<br />This course is an advanced undergraduate course on the history of the Italian
avant-garde, with an emphasis on key political debates, aesthetic developments,
and experimental practices in Italian Modernism and post-war art. It is taught
in tandem with the research resources in London.<br />
The course will
unfold chronologically. Starting with Divisionism and ending with Arte Povera
it will map the development of modern and post-war Italian art. Seminal
movements such as Futurism, Metaphysical Art, Informel and Arte Povera will be
tackled along with in focus classes devoted to singular artists, such as
Giorgio Morandi, Lucio Fontana and Michelangelo Pistoletto, amongst others.
Attention will also be given to contemporary developments in the fields of
design and film and how these in turn inflected the dialogue around art.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3104 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: Modern and Contemporary: The Body and its Vicissitudes - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: Rye Holmboe<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Fridays 11am-1pm.<br />
This course examines
notions of embodiment in performance through its interdisciplinary relationship
with dance, theatre, painting, sculpture, and
video/television in modern and contemporary art. We consider the
mobilisation of the body as a critique of bourgeois modernity. Equally, we analyse
performance and embodiment as therapeutic, pedagogical or transformative
processes, and as attempts to form different modes of consciousness. Some
of the areas explored include: Antonin Artaud and the Theatre of Cruelty;
Isadora Duncan and the advent of free dance; Samuel Beckett, absurdity and
negation; the figure of the marionette in the history of modern art;
performance and counterculture in the 1960s, particularly as it relates to
anti-psychiatry; the place of performance within feminist art; the
relationship between gender identification, race and queer
subjectivity; the current interest in dance within contemporary art;
and the positioning of performance within participation and relational
aesthetics.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3105 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: The Early Modern Technologies of Vision - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: Rosemary Moore<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Wednesdays 11am-1pm.<br />
 This course will examine
the impact of new technologies of vision (for example: print, optical lenses,
systems of perspective etc.) and ask: how did these shape the production and
dissemination of knowledge in early modern Europe? From botanical illustrations
by Dürer to studies of the human anatomy by Leonardo, Raphael and other
artists, we will examine artworks that seem to suggest a renewed interest in
the study of the natural world, along with woodcuts and engravings from medical
or ‘scientific’ treatises. Some of the earliest known European images of the
landscapes and peoples of the so called ‘New World’ of the Americas will also
be addressed. Print will be central to our discussion of these ‘new
technologies of vision’ and while it is often conceptualised as a medium that
transmits clear, verifiable and accurately replicable information about the
world, we will also consider some of the problems that this language masks.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3205 Art and Visual Culture in Early Modern England - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/diana-dethloff">Diana Dethloff</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Thursdays 2-4pm.<br />
This course examines art
production, patronage and performance in the formative period of Britain’s
artistic history, covering the period from 1558 to c. 1650. Topics will
include: the importance of the visual arts in the ‘cult’ of monarchy, in
particular Elizabeth I; ephemeral spectacles such as masques, progresses and
courtly entertainments; the representation of power and authority; the
representation of women; the representation of dress and fashion; the influence
of continental practice on English art and architecture; printed and medallic
imagery; studio training and workshop practice; the effects of the Civil War on
established patronage systems and art collecting and the beginnings of an art
market.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3221 Technologies in Art - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff" target="_self">Matilde Nardelli</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Thursdays 4-6pm.<br />
This
course explores the relation between the moving image and art from the
beginning of the 20th century to the present, providing a historical and critical
context for the ‘cinematic turn’ of contemporary art and the diffusion of the
moving image in culture at large. Though the course follows a roughly
chronological order, the sessions are arranged thematically, exploring a number
of theoretical concerns in the history of the moving image, and the way in
which these concerns are articulated in a diverse body of moving-image works
spanning from classics of the historical avant-garde and experimental cinema
such as René Clair’s Entr’acte (1924) and Hollis Frampton’s (nostalgia) (1971)
to video art, contemporary gallery installations and internet-based films.
Taking as its main focus the – changing – material base of the moving image,
from the celluloid of photochemical cinema to the digital code of contemporary
video, the course will not only trace a history of the moving image in art, but
also introduce some of the ways in which such image has been theorized as art.
Through analysis of a range of works and critical texts (from ‘theories’ of the
moving image to reflections on the medium on the part of practitioners
themselves) we will situate debates about the sometimes contested status of the
moving image as art, its aesthetics and materiality, its novelty and
obsolescence, against the wider horizon of technological and media changes and
their cultural impact.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart3221">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3226 Architecture and the Modern City - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutor: Jacob Paskins<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Tuesdays 11am-1pm.<br />Architecture is
inhabitable, multi-dimensional space. But film, photography, drawings and texts
provide much of our understanding of architecture and the modern city. This
course asks what different forms of architectural dissemination can tell us
about the design and meaning of buildings and urban space. How does cinema,
television and radio represent architecture to a mass public? How has
architecture become a touchstone in the art of comics? How do written texts
including guidebooks and magazines communicate architectural knowledge to
diverse audiences? How do manifestos and the architecture book transmit new
ideas about architectural design? Asking these questions, we will explore how
historians have used these different modes of architectural representation to
write the history of architecture in the twentieth century. Finally, we will
consider how these varied artefacts continue to inspire architecture and urban
design.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3235 Documentary Work: American Media in the 1930s - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Simon Constantine<br /><strong>Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Mondays 2-4pm.<br />
This course examines the rise of documentary practice in the United
States in the 1930s. Framed by the U.S. government’s systematic use of
photography as means to remedy the Depression and orchestrate Franklin D.
Roosevelt’s New Deal, the course organizes a media history of documentary
work—in books, films, and illustrated magazines. Students will be encouraged to
mine the overlaps and intersections between these media, and to develop a
history of documentary practices in the United States that exceeds the strictures
of modernism’s medium specificities. In addition to bridging the gap between
histories of media and exploring the relationship between the rise of
documentary work and the emergence of new mass media, this course also aims to
address the multiple and radical politics of documentary film and photography
in America. Course materials include the books, films, and illustrated
portfolios produced by America’s documentary vanguard, including Walker Evans,
Margaret Bourke-White, Paul Strand, and Pare Lorentz, as well as more recent
studies of documentary practices and media histories.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3241 Psycho - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/mignon-nixon">Mignon Nixon</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Thursdays 11am-1pm.<br />
From the
Surrealist revolution to the present, art, film, and visual culture have seized
on radical ideas of psychoanalysis to articulate—to connect—subjectivity and
politics. The unconscious, the symptom, hysteria, polymorphous perversity, the
death drive, the uncanny, fetishism, melancholia, resistance and transference
are just some of the psychoanalytic propositions that inform the making and the
interpretation of critical modes of art from Freud’s time to our own. This
course looks at dynamic interactions of art, psychoanalysis, and politics. It
also considers dissident theories and practices of psychoanalysis in the
perspective of representation. It involves in-depth reading of psychoanalytic
texts and of art-historical and critical literature in which psychoanalysis is
brought to bear. Particular emphasis is given to discourses of feminism and
gender in their critical engagement with psychoanalysis and to psychoanalytic
theories of violence and war.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3242 Early Modern Metamorphosis - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/allison-stielau">Allison Stielau</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Mondays 11am-1pm.<br />
Metamorphosis—the
total change of one form into another—has been a major subject of art
since antiquity. This course takes up topics of metamorphosis in
early modern art and material culture. The first term will focus on the
representation of transformation. Students will become familiar both with
Ovid’s Metamorphoses (in modern and early modern translation) and
with responses to that text by artists ranging from Pollaiuolo, Bernini, and
Rubens to anonymous masters in all media. We seek to understand the appeal
and the challenge of transformation for the visual artist. In the second term
we will consider physical and conceptual transformations of artworks
themselves. Topics include processes of conversion and secularization,
adaptation and recycling, the recovery and reframing of spolia (ancient fragments), and the shifting purposes and meanings
of artworks through time and across varied cultural contexts.<strong><br />Duration</strong><strong>
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
</dl>
 

</div>


<hr class="rule" />

<h2 class="heading"></h2>





<p class="p"><strong></strong></p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                    </div>

                    </div>

                <li class="footer__item"><a href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/enterprise">Businesses</a></li>
                <li class="footer__item"><a href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/media">Media Relations</a></li>
                <li class="footer__item"><a href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/hr/jobs/">Jobs</a></li>
                <li class="footer__item"><a href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/alumni/donations-gbp-single?PROJECT_CODE=U00003">Support us</a></li>
            </ul>
        </article>

        <div class="clearfix"></div>

        <ul id="social" class="list-inline">

                    <div class="site-content__main">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 
<h1 class="heading">Course Selection Guidance</h1>

<h2 class="heading">MAKING YOUR COURSE CHOICES </h2>





<table class="silvatable silvatable list" width="100%" cellspacing="0" cellpadding="3">
<col width="100%" class="align-left" />
<tbody>
<tr class="odd">
<td class="align-left">
  
  You will find yourself referred to below by the abbreviation <strong>SH</strong> (Single
Honours, History of Art), <strong>HAMS</strong> (History of art with Material Studies),
<strong>CHSOAS</strong> (Combined Honours with SOAS), or<strong> CH</strong> (Combined Honours with
another subject).

</td>
</tr>
</tbody>
</table>
<p class="p"> <strong>THE COURSE UNIT DEGREE</strong><br /><br />A UCL degree
 in History of Art, History of Art with Material Studies, and the 
various combined degrees taught in the department, is made up of twelve 
course units taught over three years. You can take a maximum of four 
units in any one year. A course unit is an entity made up according to a
 formula, in essence it is 'standard' of teaching and learning elements;
 use of this formula allows Universities to measure and ensure 
equivalence across a range of different disciplines in different places 
and learning environments. As far as you are concerned, in History of 
Art, in UCL's Faculty of Social and Historical Sciences, a course unit 
consists of: two hours of classes a week across two terms, preparatory 
reading for each class, contribution to the classes in the form of one 
or more presentations to the seminar, one essay due in each of the two 
terms and a 3-hour examination in the third term. A half unit course is 
half of that - a course usually lasting one term requiring one essay, 
and a 2-hour examination in the third term.<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>INFORMATION FOR ARRIVING FIRST-YEAR STUDENTS</strong></p>
<p class="p"> First-year students are confronted with a confusing range 
of choices and decisions, all of which require their urgent attention. 
This short guide will explain what you need to know as regards making 
choices and decisions about courses.</p>
<p class="p"> LOGGING ON TO PORTICO, PRE-REGISTERED COURSES<br />When you 
register as a UCL student you will be given a student id and a password 
so that you can log on to the college computer system. This can be done 
in any one of the computer rooms around college (and halls of 
residence), or you can use your own machine connected via the college 
wi-fi system, or even log on using your own ISP. <br />Among the many 
things you must do is get acquainted with the PORTICO system. This is 
the on-line course and examination registration system. When you open 
your account you will find that you are already registered for two 
course units: HART1001 (The Core Course) and both HART1305 and HART1306 
(The Foundation Courses). The Core Course is worth one course unit, the 
Foundation Courses half a unit each. For CHSOAS and all other CH 
students this represents all of your History of Art courses for the 
first year.<br /><br />CHOOSING YOUR SUBSIDIARY SUBJECT<br />SH students are 
obliged to take two units in a subsidiary subject (Archaeology, 
Anthropology, History, Philosophy; note that both these units must be in
 the same discipline). These can be taken at any time during the three 
years, but we recommend that you do a full unit in your first year. 
Normally, if you choose the Anthropology subsidiary, you will take  
ANTH1002 and ANTH1004 (Introduction to Material Culture and Visual 
Culture parts I and II; two 0.5 cu courses which run consecutively in 
the autumn and spring terms). For Archaeology you will normally take 
ARCL1007 (Interdisciplinary Approaches to Archaeological Problems, a 1.0
 cu running through both terms). The History subsidiary option is 
normally HIST1001 (From the Ancient Near-East to the 21st Century, this 
is the History departments Core Course, a 1.0 cu option running over 
both terms). Those wishing to take Philosophy should consult their 
website and choose a unit's worth of first-level philosophy courses. All
 students, whatever their choice of subsidiary, should register directly
 on PORTICO unless advised otherwise at the beginning of term meeting. 
One final thing: pay attention to the timetables for the course(s) you 
choose. When you have chosen and registered for your subsidiary 
course(s) you will be registered for three and a half units - the two 
units for which all our first-year students are pre-registered, a half 
unit of a language (or other), and a unit of a subsidiary subject. You 
have half a unit left.<br /><br />THEMATIC SEMINARS<br />At the first meeting 
of term you will be told about the Thematic Seminars (HART1304 and 
HART1307). These are small group seminars (maximum 15 students) taught 
both in the classroom, and in museums and galleries. If you are a SH or 
HAMS student, you will be given a choice form so that you can state your
 preference from the topics on offer. By the end of the first week we 
will get back to you, letting you know which class you will be joining. 
At this point you will know which four units you will be doing in your 
first year, and you will be able to complete your PORTICO registration 
accordingly.<br /><br />HAMS COURSES<br />As noted above, HAMS students must 
either pass the language test, or take a half unit at the UCL Language 
Centre. HAMS students also choose a Thematic Seminar (see above). 
Instead of taking a subsidiary, however, HAMS students have two History 
of Art half-unit courses set aside for them: HART1302 (Methods and 
Materials of Artists) and HART1303 (Science for Art Historians). We 
expect you to take both of these. With your two pre-registered units, 
half a unit of a language, half a unit of Thematic Seminar and the two 
HAMS half units, you will be able to complete your PORTICO registration.<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>INFORMATION FOR FIRST-YEAR STUDENTS GOING IN TO THE SECOND YEAR</strong><br /></p>
<p class="p"> All second-year courses are half-unit courses, taught over 
the ten weeks of either the Autumn or Spring terms. Most are ‘period 
courses’ but a number are designed for particular aspects of the various
 programmes taught in the department. <br /></p>
<p class="p"> GATEWAY COURSES<br />We want you to continue to develop a 
broad historical overview during
the second year. For this reason we have instituted the 'Gateway
Courses' which will ensure that every second-year student in the
department will take at least one 'earlier period' and one 'later 
period'
course. Gateway Courses are
 larger-scale versions of the usual second-year period lecture/seminar 
period courses.<br /><br />'METHODS' COURSES<br />This is a term we use to 
describe HART2001 (History of the Category ‘Art’), HART2002 (Current 
Methodologies of Art History) and HART2005 (Methodologies of Making). 
These are courses designed specifically for SH,  HAMS and  CHSOAS 
students. SH and HAMS students are required to choose at least two out 
of the three; CHSOAS students must choose at least one from HART2001, 2 
and 5. The courses are also open to any other student who would like to 
learn about and engage with the issues raised in these classes.<br /><br />'HAMS' COURSES<br />HART2238
 (Materials and Methods II), HART2239 (History and Technology of Textiles) and HART2217 (Practice, Theory and History 
of Conservation) are provided specifically for History of Art  with 
Material Studies students. Owing to the laboratory/studio nature of the 
classes, numbers are limited and there are unlikely to be any spaces 
available for other History of Art students. Non-HAMS students wishing 
to take either of the HAMS courses should contact the Director of 
Studies by email, arguing their case.<br /><br />YOUR CHOICES<br />SH students
 normally take four period courses; two are already chosen (i.e., the  
Gateway Courses), you may choose the others from the list. You must also
 choose two out of the three 'methods' courses (see above). You may take
 all three 'methods' courses if you wish but you will have to drop one 
period course and will need to make a good case; consult a teacher and 
support your choice with an email to the Director of Studies. Remember 
that as SH students you also have to leave at least half a unit for your
 subsidiary (Archaeology, Anthropology, History or Philosophy). You 
should contact your subsidiary department well in advance to discover 
your options for your second year.<br />HAMS students normally take at 
least three period courses (two are already chosen) plus both of the 
HAMS courses (HART2216-7, see above) to which you may add a lab-based 
course elsewhere (consult with the HAMS tutor); you must also choose at 
least one from HART2001, 2 and 5 (see above).<br /><br />CHSOAS students 
take at least three period courses; two are already chosen. You are also
 required to have taken at least one of the three 'methods' courses (see
 above) before you graduate; you can do this in your second or third 
year - we recommend you do it in your second year.<br />CH students 
normally take at least two History of Art course units in their second 
year. The rules of your particular combination can vary, please check 
with
your parent department, but you may choose to take as few as one and a
half course units with us. One unit is already covered by the two 
Gateway Courses. You can choose up to two other courses from the list 
and may, if you wish, include one of the 'methods' course (see above).<br /><br />TIMETABLE &amp; WORKLOAD<br />We
 have tried to avoid clashes between our own courses and courses taught 
in departments with which we share Combined Honours degrees. We have 
also sought to avoid clashing with subsidiary courses taught in the 
Anthropology, Archaeology History and Philosophy departments. You should
 ensure that you do not make your life complicated by remembering to 
check the timetabling of your choices before registering on PORTICO. We 
do not expect you to take more than half of your courses in any one term
 and will not normally allow you to put yourself under too much pressure
 in that way. But if you feel you have a good case for such a choice you
 should support it with an email to the Director of Studies.<br /><br />GETTING ONTO YOUR PREFERRED COURSES<br />We
 set up the Gateway Courses so that the pressure of numbers would be 
relieved on the other period courses, enabling them to run as proper 
seminars. Some courses will prove to be more  attractive to students and
 it may happen that you will be unable to get on to your first choice. <br /><br /></p>
<p class="p"> <strong>INFORMATION FOR SECOND-YEAR STUDENTS GOING IN TO THE FINAL YEAR<br /> (INCLUDING RETURNING 'YEAR ABROAD' STUDENTS)</strong><br /></p>
<p class="p"> All History of Art students have to take at least one 
'Special Subject' course unit in their final year. All final year 
Special Subjects are of one course unit value.<br />SH and HAMS students 
will find that they are already pre-registered for a dissertation: 
respectively HART3904 (Undergraduate Report) or HART3907 (History of Art
 and
                Material Studies Project Paper). <br /></p>
<p class="p"> SINGLE HONOURS STUDENTS<br />SH students will do at least one
 UCL History of Art Special Subject and the Undergraduate Report, as 
stated above. You can choose to do a second and third UCL History of Art
 Special Subject, or you can opt for an appropriate one course unit 
Special Subject seminar from outside UCL (at Birkbeck College or SOAS). 
Such a choice will require forms to be filled in, and you should consult
 the Director of Studies. You may choose to take a course unit in 
another part of UCL (for example at the Bartlett School, or in the 
Institute of Archaeology). You may also put together a diet of 
appropriate half-unit course units in this department, including the 
Independent Study Essay (HART3906). You may choose to do one of these 
plus a second-year History of Art half-unit course, or a half unit in 
another UCL department. We ask that you clear any unusual combinations 
with the Director of Studies first. Whatever you choose to do you should
 ensure that you do not overload one or other term with courses. And if 
you still have a half-unit of subsidiary work to take, you should be 
careful not to complicate your timetable.<br /><br />HISTORY OF ART WITH MATERIAL STUDIES STUDENTS<br />HAMS
 students will take two UCL History of Art Special Subjects, HART3907 
(The Project Paper), and up to a unit’s worth of other appropriate 
courses. These may include lab-based  courses in another UCL department 
(to be identified by the students and approved by HAMS course tutors) or
 the half-unit Independent Study Essay (HART3906).</p>
<p class="p"> <br />COMBINED HONOURS WITH SOAS STUDENTS<br />CHSOAS students 
will normally take two course units of History of Art in their final 
year. This would normally consist of two Special Subjects, or one 
Special Subject and the HART3904 Undergraduate Report. Remember that you
 are expected to have taken one of the methods courses (HART2001 2 and 
5, see above in advice for students entering the second year) by the end
 of your degree course. If you did not do this in the second year you 
must do so in the final year.<br /><br />COMBINED HONOURS AND RETURNING 'YEAR ABROAD' STUDENTS<br />CH
 students must normally take two History of Art course units in their 
final year. (Some combinations allow you to do as few as one and a half 
History of Art course units in the final year, depending on how many 
History of Art course units you took in your second year.) Normally you 
would take one UCL History of Art Special Subject and either a second 
Special Subject, or the Undergraduate Report (HART3904), or an 
appropriate one course unit from outside the department (as noted above 
under SH), or, if you wish only to do a further half unit, an 
appropriate course of that value from within the History of Art 
department, SOAS or the Bartlett School. </p>


<!-- End Silva content --> 

                        </article>

                    <div class="content-footer">
                                        <hr />
                <div id="content-footer"></div>

                            <!-- Start Silva content -->

                    <div class="content-footer">

                        <article class="article clearfix">
                            <!-- Start Silva content --> 

<html>

    
        <script>
            require(["theme/ug-tabs"]);
            require(["theme/ug"]);
        </script>
        <script>var ajaxyear = '2018';
                                    var ajaxroot = 'http://www.ucl.ac.uk/indigo-ucl-prospectus-undergraduate';</script>

        
            
                
                

                   <div class="prospectus--programme--last">
                        

                        <h2>History of Art with Material Studies BA</h2>

                        
                            <div class="copy__section copy__anchor scrollspy" id="standfirst">
                                <p class="copy__intro">This degree provides a unique focus on works of art as physical objects. You will gain comprehensive skills in art history, together with a thorough understanding of artists' techniques and questions of materiality, both at the time a work of art was made, and subsequently as it ages and deteriorates.</p>
                            </div>
                        

                        
        
                        
            
                        

                        

                        

                        

                        
                        
                        
            
                        

                        
                    </div>
                
            
        
    
</html>
<hr class="rule" />






<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Key Facts</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>

<div class="prebox">
<section class="box box--None">
  
  <i class="fa None"></i> 
  
<!-- Subtemplate: 2 columns with 50/50 division -->  
<section class="middle-split"> 

  <section class="middle-split__column1"> 
    



<h4 class="heading">Degree Programme</h4>



<p class="p">History of Art with Material Studies BA </p>



<h4 class="heading">UCAS Code</h4>



<p class="p">V3F2</p>



<h4 class="heading">Duration</h4>



<p class="p">3 years</p>



<h4 class="heading">Application Deadline</h4>



<p class="p">15 January 2017</p>



<h4 class="heading">Subject area</h4>



<p class="p"><a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/subject-areas/history-art" target="_self">History of Art</a></p>


  </section> 
 
  <section class="middle-split__column2"> 
    



<h4 class="heading">Faculty overview:</h4>



<p class="p"> <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/shs" target="_self">
          Faculty of Social and Historical Sciences</a> </p>



<h4 class="heading">Department website:</h4>



<p class="p"> <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history" target="_self">History of Art</a> </p>



<h4 class="heading">Total intake (by subject area)</h4>



<p class="p">65
                                                (2016 entry)
                                            </p>



<h4 class="heading">Applications per place (by subject area)</h4>



<p class="p">8 (2015 entry)
                                            </p>



<h4 class="heading">Research Excellence Framework</h4>



<p class="p">85% rated 4* (‘world-leading’) or 3* (‘internationally excellent’)</p>
<p class="p">What is the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ref2014">Research Excellence Framework?</a></p>

 
      <!-- right content block --> 
  </section> 
</section>



</section>

</div>


</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Entry</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div><h1 class="heading">Entry</h1>
<html>

    
        <script>
            require(["theme/ug-tabs"]);
            require(["theme/ug"]);
        </script>
        <script>var ajaxyear = '2018';
                                    var ajaxroot = 'http://www.ucl.ac.uk/indigo-ucl-prospectus-undergraduate';</script>

        
            
                
                

                   <div class="prospectus--programme--last">
                        

                        <h2>History of Art BA</h2>

                        

                        
        
                        
                            <section class="copy__section copy__anchor collapse scrollspy" id="entry-requirements">
                                <h3 class="copy__heading collapse__header">Entry requirements</h3>
                                
                                <div class="collapse__content">
                                    <h4>A Levels</h4>
                                    <dl class="dl-inline">
                                        <dt>Grades</dt>
                                        <dd>AAA-ABB</dd>
                                        <dt>Subjects</dt>
                                        <dd>No specific subjects, though essay-based subjects are an advantage.</dd>
                                        
                                        
                                        <dt>GCSEs</dt>
                                        <dd>English Language at grade B or 6, plus Mathematics at grade C or 5. For UK-based students a foreign language at grade B or 6 is required.</dd>
                                    </dl>
                                    <h4>IB Diploma</h4>
                                    <dl class="dl-inline">
                                        <dt>Points</dt>
                                        <dd>34-38</dd>
                                        <dt>Subjects</dt>
                                        <dd>A score of 16-17 points in three higher level subjects, with no score lower than 5. A minimum of grade 4 is required at standard level in a modern language.</dd>
                                    </dl>
                                    
                                    <h5>UK applicants qualifications</h5>
                                    <p>For entry requirements with other UK qualifications accepted by UCL, choose your qualification from the list below:</p>
                                    <div class="dropdown">
                                        <select class="dropdown__inner dropdown_uk_qualifications">
                                            <option
    id="resetit-UBAHARSING05">Select qualification</option>
                                            <option
    id="btec-UBAHARSING05">BTEC National Diploma</option>
                                            <option
    id="accessCourse-UBAHARSING05">Access to HE Diploma</option>
                                            <option
    id="preU-UBAHARSING05">Cambridge Pre-U Principal Subjects</option>
                                            <option
    id="scotAdvancedHighers-UBAHARSING05">Scottish Advanced Highers</option>
                                            <option
    id="welshBacc-UBAHARSING05">Welsh Baccalaureate</option>
                                        </select>
                                    </div>
                                    <div
    class="box box--copy">
                                        <h5
    class="alt-qualifications__hidden alt-qualifications__hidden-UBAHARSING05"
    id="info-heading">Equivalent qualification</h5>
                                        <p
    class="alt-qualifications__hidden alt-qualifications__hidden-UBAHARSING05"
    id="info-btec-UBAHARSING05">BTEC Level 3 Extended Diploma (QCF) or BTEC Level 3 National Extended Diploma (RQF - teaching from 2016) with Distinction, Distinction, Distinction.</p>
                                        <p
    class="alt-qualifications__hidden alt-qualifications__hidden-UBAHARSING05"
    id="info-accessCourse-UBAHARSING05">Pass in Access to HE Diploma, with 18 credits awarded with distinction in the Level 3 units, the remainder of the Level 3 units with Merit.  Or a minimum of 28 credits awarded with Merit in the Level 3 units.</p>
                                        <p
    class="alt-qualifications__hidden alt-qualifications__hidden-UBAHARSING05"
    id="info-preU-UBAHARSING05">D3,D3,D3 - D3,M1,M1 in three Cambridge Pre-U Principal Subjects.</p>
                                        <p
    class="alt-qualifications__hidden alt-qualifications__hidden-UBAHARSING05"
    id="info-scotAdvancedHighers-UBAHARSING05">AAA-ABB at Advanced Highers (or AB at Advanced Higher and BBB at Higher - AA at Advanced Higher and AAA at Higher).</p>
                                        <p
    class="alt-qualifications__hidden alt-qualifications__hidden-UBAHARSING05"
    id="info-welshBacc-UBAHARSING05">Successful completion of the WBQ Advanced Skills Challenge Certificate plus 2 GCE A-Levels at grades AAA-ABB.</p>
                                    </div>
                                    
                                        <h4>International applications</h4>
                                        <p>In addition to A level and International Baccalaureate, UCL considers a wide range of international qualifications for entry to its undergraduate degree programmes.</p>

                                        <div class="box box--copy">
                                            <p
    class="equiv-content equiv-content-UBAHARSING05"></p>
                                        </div>
                                    
                                    <h4>Undergraduate Preparatory Certificates</h4>
                                    <p>The Undergraduate Preparatory Certificates (UPCs) are intensive one-year foundation courses for international students of high academic potential who are aiming to gain access to undergraduate degree programmes at UCL and other top UK universities.</p>
                                    <p>Typical UPC students will be high achievers in a 12-year school system which does not meet the standard required for direct entry to UCL.</p>
                                    <p>For more information see: <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/upc" >www.ucl.ac.uk/upc</a>.</p>
                                    <h4>English language requirements</h4>
                                    <p>If your education has not been conducted in the English language, you will be expected to demonstrate evidence of an adequate level of English proficiency. Information about the evidence required, acceptable qualifications and test providers can be found on our <a href='http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/application/requirements/english-requirements'>English language requirements</a> page.</p>
                                    <p>The English language level for this programme is: <b>Good</b></p>
                                    <p>A variety of English language programmes are offered at the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/clie">UCL Centre for Languages & International Education</a>.</p>
                                </div>
                            </section>
                        
            
                        

                        

                        

                        

                        
                        
                        
            
                        

                        
                    </div>
                
            
        
    
</html>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Application</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div><h1 class="heading">Application</h1>
<html>

    
        <script>
            require(["theme/ug-tabs"]);
            require(["theme/ug"]);
        </script>
        <script>var ajaxyear = '2018';
                                    var ajaxroot = 'http://www.ucl.ac.uk/indigo-ucl-prospectus-undergraduate';</script>

        
            
                
                

                   <div class="prospectus--programme--last">
                        

                        <h2>History of Art BA</h2>

                        

                        
        
                        
            
                        

                        

                        

                        

                        
                            <section class="copy__section copy__anchor collapse scrollspy zero-bottom" id="application">
                                <h3 class="copy__heading collapse__header">Application and next steps</h3>

                                <div class="collapse__content">
                                    
                                    
                                        <h4>Your application</h4>
                                        <p><p>We welcome applicants who have a serious interest in, and enthusiasm for, the study of art history. Entry is highly competitive, but you will not be required to have studied history of art before. However, advanced study in an essay-based subject such as history or English, as well as a language, would be an advantage.</p></p>
                                    
                                    <h4>How to apply</h4>
                                    <p>Application for admission should be made through UCAS (the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service). Applicants currently at school or college will be provided with advice on the process; however, applicants who have left school or who are based outside the United Kingdom may obtain information directly from UCAS.</p>
                                    
                                    <p>
                                        <strong>Application deadline:</strong>
                                        15 January 2018                    
                                    </p>
                                    
                                    <br />
                                    <ul class="list-unstyled list-inline list-inline--btn hidden-lg">
                                        <li>
                                            
                                                    <a
    class="btn cta" href="http://www.ucas.com"
    onclick="_gaq.push(['_trackEvent','UG (widget) apply clicks','Click','http://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/hams-ba'])">Apply through UCAS</a>
                                          
                                        </li>
                                        <li>
                                            <a
    href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/undergraduate/application/application/how-to-apply">Application guidelines</a>
                                        </li>
                                    </ul> 
                                    <br /><br />
                                    <h4>Selection</h4>
                                    <p><p>Applicants will be assessed not only on academic achievement, but on evidence of intellectual curiosity, and of critical appreciation of visual culture.</p></p>
                                    <p><p>If we are considering making you an offer you will be asked to complete a short written exercise, and then invited to the department on an open day to meet the teaching staff and learn more about the degree programme.</p></p>
                                    <p>For further information on UCL's selection process see: <a href='http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/application/selection'>Selection of students</a>.</p>
                                    <ul class="list-unstyled list-inline list-inline--btn hidden-lg">
                                        <li><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/ucl-plus" class="btn btn--secondary">Request a printed prospectus <i class="icon icon--book icon--push-left pull-right"></i></a>
                                        </li>
                                        <li><a href="//www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/download" class="btn btn--secondary">Download prospectus <i class="icon icon--download icon--push-left pull-right"></i></a>
                                        </li>
                                    </ul>
                                    <br /><br />
                                </div>
                            </section>
                        
                        
                        
                            <section>

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Degree Summary</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div><h1 class="heading">Degree Summary</h1>
<html>

    
        <script>
            require(["theme/ug-tabs"]);
            require(["theme/ug"]);
        </script>
        <script>var ajaxyear = '2018';
                                    var ajaxroot = 'http://www.ucl.ac.uk/indigo-ucl-prospectus-undergraduate';</script>

        
            
                
                

                   <div class="prospectus--programme--last">
                        

                        <h2>History of Art BA</h2>

                        

                        
        
                        
            
                        
                            <section class="copy__section copy__anchor collapse scrollspy" id="degree-benefits">
                                <h3 class="copy__heading collapse__header">Degree benefits</h3>
                                <div class="collapse__content">
                                    <ul>
                                        <li><p>High-quality research undertaken by staff, which is reflected in our research excellence profile, informs the content of our undergraduate courses, keeping our teaching at the forefront of the discipline.</p></li>
                                        <li><p>We have specialists on all periods from the medieval onwards, with particular strengths in the study of contemporary art, as well as experts in material studies.</p></li>
                                        <li><p>UCL Art Museum houses an important collection of artworks, which is used regularly to support our teaching. These include works by Turner and Rembrandt, as well as important 20th-century prints. The UCL Institute of Making is also used regularly in our teaching.</p></li>
                                        <li><p>UCL's central location in London is within walking distance of the British Museum and British Library and provides easy access to the National Gallery, the Tate Galleries and the Victoria and Albert Museum.</p></li>
                                    </ul>
                                    
                                    
                                        <h2>Research Excellence Framework (REF) 2014</h2>
                                        <p>The <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/ref2014">Research Excellence Framework</a>, or REF, is the system for assessing the quality of research in UK higher education institutions. The 2014 REF was carried out by the UK's higher education funding bodies, and the results used to allocate research funding from 2015/16.</p>
                                        
                                        <p>The following REF score was awarded to the department: History of Art.</p>
                                        <ul>
                                            <li>85% rated 4* (&#145;world-leading&#146;) or 3* (&#145;internationally excellent&#146;)</li>
                                        </ul>
                                        <p>Learn more about the scope of UCL's research, and browse case studies, on our <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/impact/">Research Impact website</a>.</p>
                                    
                                    
                                        <h2>Video</h2>
                                        <p>A short video with more information.</p>
                                        <div class="video-wrap">
                                            <iframe
    width="560" height="315"
    src="//www.youtube.com/embed/4zRcu6DFKRM"
    frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
                                        </div>
                                        <p>
                                            <span class="youtube-icon"></span>
                                            Subscribe to the <a href="http://www.youtube.com/user/StudyUCL">StudyUCL YouTube channel</a> to learn more about life and studying at UCL.
                                        </p>
                                    
                                    
                                </div>
                            </section>
                        

                        

                        

                        

                        
                        
                        
            
                        

                        
                    </div>
                
            
        
    
</html>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Degree Structure</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div><h1 class="heading">Degree Structure</h1>
<script>
                require(['app/tabs']);
            </script>
<div class="tabs">
    <nav role="navigation" class="tabs__navigation"><ul>
  
   

    



        
            <li>

<a class="active" href="#tab-1">Year 1</a>


</li>
        
    
    



        
            <li>


<a href="#tab-2">Year 2</a>

</li>
        
    
    



        
            <li>


<a href="#tab-3">Year 3</a>

</li>
        
    
    



        
            <li>


<a href="#tab-4">Teaching Methods</a>

</li>
        
    
    



        
            <li>


<a href="#tab-5">Tailoring your Degree Programme</a>

</li>
        
    
    </ul></nav>
<div class="tabs__group">
    
        
            
<div class="tabs__item tab active" id="tab-1">
<div class="tab__content"><h2 class="heading">Year 1</h2>
<p class="p">In their first year students are 
introduced to a range of narratives and procedures and to the techniques
 of close scrutiny of objects and other evidence, as well as to ways of 
combining the two. They learn something of the way the discipline has 
been constructed, to give them training in a range of intellectual and 
procedural tools and to enable them to begin to think critically about 
different approaches to the subject. The tasks students have to perform 
in this stage train them to work within guidelines and to deadlines, and
 develop their ability to undertake investigations in libraries and 
galleries, to use other resources as appropriate, and to write relevant 
expositions of evidence and coherent arguments from evidence. It will 
also develop their ability to benefit from a variety of teaching and 
learning modes, including how to work with teachers and colleagues in a 
seminar. They also acquire or reinforce necessary ancillary skills in 
foreign languages and in presentation, including word-processing. As 
appropriate, they develop an understanding of another area of study, 
from which skills and bodies of knowledge will in the second and third 
stages become available to cross-fertilise those they acquire on the 
History of Art course.</p>


<h4 class="heading">Compulsory courses</h4>




<p class="p">History of Art and its Objects<br />History of European Art (1): Classical to Early Renaissance<br />History of European Art (2): High Renaissance to the Present Day<br /></p>


<h4 class="heading">Optional courses</h4>




<p class="p">You will select 1.5 credits from the following:<br /><br /></p>
<p class="p">History of Art Thematic
Seminar (wide range of options available)</p>
<p class="p">HAMS-specific courses, such
as ‘Science for Art Historians’ and ‘Materials and Methods I’</p>
<p class="p"> </p>
<p class="p"> (The
content of the HAMS options is subject to variation. These are the offerings
for 2016-17.)</p>

</div>
</div>




        

    
    
        



<div class="tabs__item tab" id="tab-2">
<div class="tab__content"><h2 class="heading">Year 2</h2>
<p class="p">In
 the second year, through exposure to more complex and specialised 
debates, students develop their ability to identify and deploy art historical discourses. They do this in relation to specific problems
 and topics, and are expected to acquire a concentration of knowledge 
within at least one period of history. As appropriate, they extend their
 skills in the close examination of objects, including the study of the 
history of techniques in art. As appropriate, they also deepen their 
understanding of the way the discipline has been constructed in the 
past, and of the debates concerning methodology which currently dominate
 the discipline. They continue to develop their ability to write 
relevant and cogent arguments within guidelines and to deadlines on the 
basis of extensive study in libraries, and their ability to work 
effectively in a variety of teaching and learning modes. In particular 
they gain competence in the skills necessary to participate productively
 in a seminar. They develop appropriate skills and bodies of knowledge 
in another discipline, and bring these, as appropriate, to bear on their
 period of specialisation and their awareness of the nature of art historical enquiry.</p>


<h4 class="heading">Compulsory courses</h4>




<p class="p"> Advanced
Lecture Course I: After Life: Art, Knowledge and Observation in Early Modern
Europe </p>
<p class="p"> Advanced
Lecture Course II: Histories of Photography</p>
<p class="p"> (The
content of the Gateway Courses changes regularly. These are the offerings for
2016-17.)</p>


<h4 class="heading">Optional courses</h4>




<p class="p">You will select 3.0 credits from a wide range of options,
including at least one of the following:
 

The History of the Category &quot;Art&quot;, Methodologies of
Art History or Methods and Materials of Artists.</p>
<p class="p"> Further options can
be selected from within History of Art, and will include 1.0 credits in
HAMS-specific courses.</p>

</div>
</div>


        

    
    
        



<div class="tabs__item tab" id="tab-3">
<div class="tab__content"><h2 class="heading">Year 3</h2>
<p class="p"> In
 the final year students continue to develop their ability to identify 
and deploy art-historical discourses, bringing this developing 
competence to bear on more highly defined problems. They acquire, as 
appropriate, the ability to locate, assess and use primary sources, and 
the ability to argue on the basis of familiarity with specialist 
literature. In most case they also develop the ability to produce an 
extended piece of writing based on a topic whose definition and 
organisation is primarily their own responsibility, which requires them 
to bring the knowledge and skills acquired in the second phase, and 
being acquired through other experience in the third phase, to bear on 
an specific but extended body of material, debate or problem. They learn
 to make better use of, and more useful contributions to, the seminar as
 a collaborative process, and to accept and discharge their part of the 
shared responsibility for its success. As appropriate, they have the 
opportunity to extend their understanding of the techniques of close 
scrutiny of objects, or of the history and methodology of Art History, 
through essay-projects of their own definition. They continue to acquire
 appropriate skills and bodies of knowledge in another discipline, and 
bring these, as relevant, to bear on their period of specialisation or 
their awareness of the nature of Art-historical enquiry.</p>


<h4 class="heading">Compulsory courses</h4>




<p class="p">Undergraduate Report in History of Art</p>


<h4 class="heading">Optional courses</h4>




<p class="p">You
 will select 3.0 credits from a wide range of options including at least
 one Special Subject. Further options can be selected from within 
History of Art, and from fields such as Anthropology, Archaeology, 
History or Philosophy.</p>

</div>
</div>


        

    
    
        



<div class="tabs__item tab" id="tab-4">
<div class="tab__content"><h2 class="heading">Teaching Methods</h2>
<p class="p">The
 department uses a variety of teaching formats: there are some lecture 
courses with follow-up discussions, but the great majority of courses 
are taught in seminar groups. These meet weekly, normally for two hours.
 Whenever it is appropriate to the objectives of the course, teaching 
takes place in museums and galleries or on visits to monuments. In 
several courses, the majority of classes take place 'in front of the 
object', and students can expect to participate in such classes in all 
three years of the course. Students are encouraged to use the very rich 
public collections and other resources which London can offer for their 
own study of art history; with some assignments based around the 
intensive study of objects or groups of objects from London collections.</p>
<p class="p">The
 department is involved in teaching a whole range of degrees, some of 
which are administered from other departments. Thus, in addition to the 
Single Honours degree in History of Art, there are Single Honours 
degrees in History of Art with Material Studies (HAMS), and the History 
of Western and Non-Western Art - the second of these is run from the 
School of African and Oriental Studies (SOAS). There are also Combined 
Honours degrees with Dutch, French, German, Italian, Philosophy, 
Scandinavian Studies and Spanish, in which History of Art comprises 
around half of the course.</p>

</div>
</div>


        

    
    
        



<div class="tabs__item tab" id="tab-5">
<div class="tab__content"><h2 class="heading">Tailoring your Degree Programme</h2>
<p class="p">The College measures
courses in terms of what are called Course Units. Some courses are half unit
courses (0.5 cu), some are whole unit courses (1.0 cu). Generally speaking,
half unit courses comprise about 20 hours teaching and last for one term, and
whole unit courses comprise about 40 hours teaching and spread over two terms.
The amount of assessment for the courses also differs proportionately. <br /></p>
<p class="p"> A full
degree course in History of Art, or History of Art with Material Studies, or
the History of Western and Non-Western Art degree at SOAS (which includes
modules taught in our Department), comprises 12 Course Units taken over
three years, as does the Combined Honours degree with
Philosophy. <br /></p>
<p class="p"> The Modern Language Plus BA comprises of 16 units as
this is a four year degree. Single Honours degree students must take 2 Course
Units of their degree in either Anthropology, or Archaeology, or History, or
Philosophy. As long as they meet the department's basic minimum requirements
for their degree programme, students can take courses in other departments of
the College subject to availability. </p>

</div>
</div>


        

    

</div>

</div>


</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">Careers</a></dt>

     <div><h1 class="heading">Careers</h1>
<html>

    
        <script>
            require(["theme/ug-tabs"]);
            require(["theme/ug"]);
        </script>
        <script>var ajaxyear = '2018';
                                    var ajaxroot = 'http://www.ucl.ac.uk/indigo-ucl-prospectus-undergraduate';</script>

        
            
                
                

                   <div class="prospectus--programme--last">
                        

                        <h2>History of Art BA</h2>

                        

                        
        
                        
            
                        

                        

                        

                            <section class="copy__section copy__anchor collapse scrollspy" id="careers">
                                <h3 class="copy__heading collapse__header">Careers</h3>
                                <div class="collapse__content">
                                    <p><p>The programme is broad and rigorous, making graduates fully competitive for jobs both within and outside the area of visual arts. The department takes seriously the need for students to develop presentational and other skills alongside the specific analytical and interpretive skills associated with history of art.</p></p>
                                    
                                        <p><p>UCL's History of Art graduates have a record of success in careers in museums and galleries, academia, the art trade, the heritage industry, art publishing, art conservation and teaching. The unique combination of visual sensitivity and intellectual rigour has also proved valuable in journalism, publishing and advertising.</p></p>
                                    
                                    <h4>Destinations</h4>
                                    <p>First destinations of recent graduates (2013-2015) of this programme include:</p>
                                    <ul>
                                        
                                            <li>Curatorial Assistant, The Frieze Art Fair</li>
                                        
                                        
                                            <li>Junior Translator, Sotheby's</li>
                                        
                                        
                                            <li>Communications Assistant, The Independent</li>
                                        
                                        
                                            <li>Parliamentary Researcher, Member of Parliament</li>
                                        
                                        
                                            <li>Full-time student, MA in History of Art at UCL</li>
                                        
                                    </ul>
                        
                                    
                                    <p
    class="small text-muted">Data taken from the 'Destinations of Leavers from Higher Education' survey undertaken by HESA looking at the destinations of UK and EU students in the 2013-2015 graduating cohorts six months after graduation.</p>
                                    <p>UCL is commited to helping you get the best start after graduation. Read more about how UCL Careers and UCL Innovation and Enterprise can <a href='http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/employability/careers-skills'>help you find employment or learn about entrepreneurship</a>.</p>
                                    
                                    
                                </div>
                            </section>

     <div><h1 class="heading">Fees and Funding</h1>

                   <div class="prospectus--programme--last">
                        

                        <h2>History of Art BA</h2>

                        

                        
        
                        
            
                        

                        

                        

                        
                            <section class="copy__section copy__anchor collapse scrollspy" id="fees-and-funding">

                                <div class="collapse__content">
                                
                                    <h4>Fees</h4>
                                    <dl class="dl-inline">
                                        <dt>UK/EU students</dt>

                                        <dt>Overseas students</dt>

                                    <p>Full details of UCL's tuition fees, tuition fee policy and potential increases to fees can be found on the <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/students/fee-schedules-2018-2019-undergraduate">UCL Students website</a>.</p>

                                    <h4>Funding</h4>
                                    <p>Various funding options are available, including student loans, scholarships and bursaries. UK students whose household income falls below a certain level may also be eligible for a non-repayable bursary or for certain scholarships. Please see the <a href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/prospective-students/undergraduate/fees-funding">Fees and funding</a> pages for more details.</p>
                                    

                                    
                                        <h4>Additional costs</h4>
                                        <p><p>Students are expected to pay the entrance fee to any admission-charging exhibition or museum visited by a class; the tutor will usually negotiate a group discount where this is significantly cheaper than the individual student discount.</p></p>
                                    
                    
                                    <h4>Departmental scholarships</h4>
                                    
                                    
                                        <p>The <a class="clicktracker scholarshipsitelink" href="http://www.ucl.ac.uk/scholarships">Scholarships and Funding</a> website lists scholarships and funding schemes available to UCL students. These may be open to all students, or restricted to specific nationalities, regions or academic department.</p>
