<hr class="rule" />

<h2 class="heading">Year 2</h2>





<p class="p"><strong>All courses are 0.5 unit courses taught in one term. Note that the courses are arranged
 with the autumn term options followed by the spring term options</strong></p>



<h4 class="heading">Autumn Term:
</h4>









<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2002 Methodologies of Art History - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutors: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/robert-mills" target="_self">Robert Mills</a> and <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/stephanie-schwartz" target="_self">Stephanie Schwartz</a><br /> <strong>Timetabled</strong>: Autumn Term: Tuesdays 11am-1pm.<br />This
text-based course introduces students to a variety of different
methodologies and approaches current in the discipline. Through
lectures, seminars and weekly reading tasks students learn to identify
and evaluate different kinds of art historical writing. Topics
addressed normally include: formalist positions in modernist criticism,
iconography, the social history of art, theories of ideology,
semiotics, discourse theory, psycho-analytic approaches, issues of
gender, sexuality and subjectivity, post-colonial theory and race and
ethnicity.<strong><br />Duration of course: </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />Student Contact Hours: </strong>20 hours, a mixture of lectures and text-based discussion classes.<strong><br />Student Workload: </strong>Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<strong><br />Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
 essays: a short Response Paper (c. 1500 words due around Reading Week 
weighted at 40%); a second essay (2000-2500 words due the last day of 
class weighted at 60%).</p>
<p class="p"> <strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Normally only offered to 2nd-year History of Art students. Other closely similar experience might be acceptable.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2002">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2011 Advanced Lecture in the History of Art: Histories of Photography - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/stephanie-schwartz" target="_self">Stephanie Schwartz</a><strong><br />Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Mondays 2-4pm.<br />
This
course surveys the history of photography from its invention in the 1830s to
its postmodern iterations in the 1970s. More specifically, it considers several
key episodes in photography’s history through discussions of the contentious
and public debates about the ways in which photography has been historicized.
Is photography an art? Is it—was it—a threat to art? Is photography something
closer to a tool or technology? Is it media? Throughout the course we will
consider the myriad ways in which these questions have been posed and pondered
by poets, critics, scientists, photographers and art historians.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Duration of Course:</strong>
 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student contact hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student 
Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, one essay, and exam.<br /><strong>Means of
 assessment: </strong>50% by essay (2000-2500 words), 50% by unseen 2 hour examination.<br /><strong>Prerequisites:

 </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art History programme 
or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2108 Modern and Contemporary Art: The Anti-Aesthetic - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Rye Holmboe<strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Wednesdays 11am-1pm.<br />
This course considers thematic categories that have
come to be associated with the anti-aesthetic: the abject, the carnivalesque,
the grotesque, the primal and the formless, among others, and thinks about the
ways in which these categories have been mobilised in modern and contemporary
art. Areas considered are, for example, the theoretical writings of Georges
Bataille; the question of the Dionysiac in the performances of the Viennese
Actionists; and the mobilisation of the body in 1960s performance art. Later
parts of the course will think about how the anti-aesthetic might be understood
in the context of the art institution and in its relationship to
commodification and the art market. This interdisciplinary course, which
considers examples from painting, sculpture, performance and theatre, explores
the extent to which anti-aesthetic categories can be seen to be transgressive,
asking what the critical and political stakes of this category might be today.<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours<strong>.<br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2202 London and Paris, c. 1700-1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff" target="_self">Susannah Walker<strong> </strong></a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Fridays 2-4pm.<br />
The course deals with the development of London and Paris as sites of 
visual fascination through their architecture, sculpture and the 
emergence of the public art exhibition alongside alternative sites of 
urban spectacle including: the theatrical performances,  public 
executions, military parades and spaces of consumption. <br />The course 
will consider mediation of London and Paris through literature, costume,
 print culture and cartography. Material will be viewed through the 
conceptual frameworks of the spectacle, &quot;modernity&quot;, the city as 
politically contested space, the official urban plan and its 
&quot;underworlds&quot;, the commodity fetish and the translation of alternative 
sensory approaches to the city (scent/ touch/ sound) to its visual 
image.<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, and 3 
perambulations around London).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2202" target="_self">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2213 Representing 'Others' c. 1700-c. 1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">  
Course tutor:<strong> </strong><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/natasha-eaton">Natasha Eaton</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Thursdays 2-4pm.<br />For the last 30 years, ‘otherness’, ‘alterity’ ‘empire’ and
postcoloniality are central to how we engage with the world. From debates
surrounding globalization, to the ways in which we are rethinking Britishness,
imperialism and its troubled legacies continue to occupy our political
landscape and to inform the entanglements of British and non-western
art. As leading anthropologist Nicholas B. Dirks warns, ‘in calling for the
study of the aesthetics of colonialism, we might end up aestheticising
colonialism, producing a radical chic version of Raj nostalgia’. With this
cautionary agenda in mind, the aim of the course is to problematise the
aesthetic and political underpinnings of these cultural encounters. Key
issues will involve images in magic and worship, the development of
Orientalism, primitivism, the role of art-as-gift, the breakdown of
realism/mimesis in the colony, the ‘translation’ of native objects into art by
the European ‘museum effect’ and the adaptation or transmutation of British
pictures by the colonised. Resistance, mimicry, hybridity and alternative
strategies for cultural exchange, will be read through post-colonial theory in
conjunction with, or against the grain of visual materials, so as to contest
art history’s ‘hegemony’ over the image-making of other places.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2214 Architecture and Modernity - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   
Course tutor: Jacob Paskins<strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Fridays 11am-1pm.<br />
Architecture today is
dominated by international design firms that produce spectacular buildings
across the world. But how did architecture become global? This course asks how
architectural knowledge and styles spread across continents during the past 150
years. We will confront how European colonialism exported architecture and
urban planning to North Africa, the Middle East and India. How did the striking
architecture of universal expositions transmit ideas about modernity? How did
the so-called International Style of modernism spread through Europe, the
United States, Japan, China and South America? Guided by the work of
postcolonial theorists and historians, we will examine the reactions to an
apparently global form of modern architecture in the twentieth century.
Ultimately, we ask if there is any room for regional difference in globalised
architectural production? <strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2217 Theory and History of Conservation - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course
 tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/hanna-hoelling">Hanna Hölling</a><strong><br />Timetabled</strong>: Autumn Term; Tuesdays 2-4pm. <br />When thinking about artworks and artefacts,
conservation provides an extensively rich area of study of their modes of
conception, creation, dissemination, display and perpetuation. This is due to
the premise that in order to engage with an artwork, conservation first and
foremost seeks to understand what the work is and how it functions within and
beyond its historic moment. Outsiders often refer to conservation as a
homogenous field of activity that aims at prolonging the cultural
objects’ lives into the future. But there are, in fact, different conservations that
operate with respect to diverse theories, types of artefacts,
institutional settings, historic contexts, and the cultures that produce
them. During this course, we will sketch a picture of
conservation that always exists between a set of dichotomies of hands and
minds, practice and theory, the tangible and the intangible, and the
traditional and the new. By putting today’s conservation into an historical
perspective, we will examine how more recent conservation became of necessity a
reflective, critical practice. Visits to museums and sites of conservation and
special tasks will enrich classroom discussions.<br /><strong>Duration 
of Course:</strong> 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student
 Workload:</strong> Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment:</strong> 2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<br /><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Students should 
have completed a first-year Art History programme or have equivalent 
relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2217">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2238 (HAMS only) Methods and Materials II - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/emma-richardson">Emma Richardson</a><strong><br />Timetabled: </strong>Autumn Term; Mondays 11am-1pm.<br />
 This course will expand on, and extend, the materials and methodologies
 covered during the first year’s course, presenting an overview of the 
major classes of materials found within museum collections, and 
addressing their application as artist’s materials. In this second 
course, focus will be given to the more obscure materials found in works
 of art, for example wax, synthetic resins, and foam. Discussion will be
 given to the types of physical properties that different materials 
exhibit, so that the student might begin to understand why an artist may
 have used a certain material.<br />
This course will provide the student with the theoretical and practical 
aspects of artists' techniques and application, and highlight some of 
the issues surrounding their preservation and conservation.<br /> <strong>Duration of Course:</strong>
 10 weeks.<br /> <strong>Student contact hours:</strong> 20+ hours in 10 weekly 2-hour classes, plus supervised lab/project work.<br /> <strong>Student 
Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, preparation for classes, independent project work.<br /> <strong>Means of
 assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<br /> <strong>Prerequisites:

 </strong>Students should have completed the first-year Art History programme 
or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2238" target="_self">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
</dl>
 

</div>


<hr class="rule" />



<h4 class="heading">Spring Term:</h4>









<div id="accordion">

<dl class="accordion">
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2001 History of the Category Art - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/mechthild-fend">Mechthild Fend</a><strong> </strong>and t.b.c.<strong><br />Timetabled</strong>: Spring; Tuesdays 11am-1pm.<br />This course aims to familiarise students with the ways in
which the concept of art has evolved in Europe. It examines the emergence of
Aesthetics as a distinct branch of philosophy in eighteenth-century in Britain,
France and Germany, and will consider subsequent nineteenth-century
developments especially in relation to the role of the category Art in
Modernism, and the ways in which it has informed more recent philosophies and
histories of art. It is based on the study of texts in Seminars.<br /><strong> Duration of course:</strong> 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours:</strong> 20 hours, a mixture of lectures and text-based discussion classes. <br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong> Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<strong><br />Means of Assessment</strong>:
 Two essays: a short Response Paper (1350-1500 words due around Reading 
Week weighted at 40%); a second essay (2000-2500 words due the last day 
of class weighted at 60%).<br /><strong>Prerequisites:</strong> Normally only offered to 2nd-year History of Art students. Other closely similar experience might be acceptable.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2001">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2005 Methodologies of Making - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/hanna-hoelling">Hannah
Hölling</a><br /> <strong>Timetabled</strong>: Spring Term; Thursday 4-6pm.<br />
This course introduces the discursive frameworks of
art production and making, remaking, collecting, mediating and conserving. It
encompasses readings and discussions centred around theories related to the
materiality and the immaterial, makers and their tools, the workings of
collections, including questions of conservation, and the notions of time and
archive. For the most part, classes will begin with a lecture followed by a
discussion. In the first part of the class, students will be introduced to
theoretical underpinnings and case studies related to the main topic of
the class. During the second part, students will try to apply these
theories to one exemplary case study of art production, curating or
conservation across the centuries. How is theory performed? How is it entangled
with practice? How can we theorise practice or develop a practical aesthetic?<strong><br />Duration of course</strong><strong>: </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />Student Workload: </strong>Attendance at all classes, prescribed and back-up reading, two pieces of written work.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Means of Assessment</strong>: Two
 essays: a short Response Paper (c. 1500 words due towards the end of 
term weighted at 40%); a second essay (2000-2500 words due at the 
beginning of the Exam term weighted at 60%).<br /><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Normally only offered to 2nd-year History of Art students. Other closely similar experience might be acceptable.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2005">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2010 Advanced Lecture in the History of Art: Early Modern Bodies - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutor: Rosemary Moore<br /><strong>Timetabled: </strong>Spring term; Mondays 2-4pm.<br />The body was at the
centre of artistic, religious and ‘scientific’ concerns throughout the period
1500–1700. These included, for example: the religious and political
controversies of the Reformation and Counter Reformation, which raised
questions over the relationship between body and image, sensation and the
sacred; the development of perspectival techniques, including anamorphosis,
which requires one to adjust the position of one’s own body in relation to the
painted image; the renewed interest in mythology and anatomy; as well as
encounters between Europeans and the peoples of the Americas. This lecture
course will engage with a range of artworks, from watercolours, frescoes and
paintings on canvas, to drawings, prints and sculpture. Case studies will include
works by well-known and celebrated artists such as Raphael, Dürer and Titian,
in addition to images that students may be less familiar with, for example
woodcuts from medical treatises or books of marvels and ‘monsters’. Today, just
as in the early modern period, the body continues to be a locus of heated
debate concerning identity, gender, race, sexuality and eroticism. Readings
will therefore encompass a wide variety of theoretical approaches to the body.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:</strong>
 10 weeks.<br /><strong>Student Contact Hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student
 Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, one essay and exam.<br /><strong>Means of Assessment: </strong>50% by essay (2000-2500 words), 50% by unseen
 2 hour examination.<strong><br />Prerequisites: </strong>Students should have 
completed a first-year Art History programme or have equivalent relevant
 experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2202 London and Paris, c. 1700-1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff" target="_self">Susannah Walker<strong> </strong></a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Fridays 2-4pm.<br />
The course deals with the development of London and Paris as sites of 
visual fascination through their architecture, sculpture and the 
emergence of the public art exhibition alongside alternative sites of 
urban spectacle including: the theatrical performances,  public 
executions, military parades and spaces of consumption. <br />The course 
will consider mediation of London and Paris through literature, costume,
 print culture and cartography. Material will be viewed through the 
conceptual frameworks of the spectacle, &quot;modernity&quot;, the city as 
politically contested space, the official urban plan and its 
&quot;underworlds&quot;, the commodity fetish and the translation of alternative 
sensory approaches to the city (scent/ touch/ sound) to its visual 
image.<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, and 3 
perambulations around London).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2202" target="_self">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2206 Modernism and the European Avant-Gardes - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Maria Mileeva<strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Thursdays 2-4pm.<br />This course will examine the history, theory and practice of
International Constructivism. Chronologically positioned in the interwar
period, the development of Constructivism will be discussed in relation to
examples of art, architecture, and design. The start of the course will locate
the origins of Constructivism in the social and political context of the
October Revolution in Russia and the radical artistic experiments in Paris,
Moscow, and Munich before the outbreak of the First World War. Outlining key
themes and interrelationships - such as utopia and revolution, artistic
experiment and mass culture - this course will relate artistic production of
the European avant-garde to the demands of politics and cultural experiment in
the turbulent period of 1920s and 1930s. The second half of the course will
address the international imperatives of Dada, Constructivism and the Bauhaus
by looking at a series of artistic and theoretical developments in Germany,
France, Poland, Hungary, and Britain. We will examine the art and writings of
Aleksandr Rodchenko, El Lissitzky, Naum Gabo, László Moholy-Nagy, Theo van
Doesburg, Kurt Schwitters, Hans Richter and Walter Gropius. The course will
critically discuss and examine the discourses of the terms modernism, avant-garde
and abstraction in their application to the theory and practice of
constructivism.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2215 Image/Object: Modernism and After - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">  
Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/briony-fer">Briony Fer</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Tuesdays 2-4pm.<br />
Course covering pivotal moments
within twentieth-century art, from the crisis of representation that triggered
the formation of the historical avant-gardes in the 1910s and 20s through to
notions of what art can look like after conceptualism that continue to shape
art practice now<strong>.<br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, including a Gallery Visit).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2229 Gender and Representation in France, c.1750–1850 - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/mechthild-fend">Mechthild Fend</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Wednesdays 11am-1pm.<br />From old regime Monarchy via the French Revolution
and the Napoleonic Empire to the Restauration the hundred years between ca 1750
and 1850 constitute not only an era of tremendous political change but also a
period in which notions of gender and sexuality, and indeed the lives of men
and women were in flux. This course explores how the visual arts engaged with
these changes and how they took part in the shaping of new ideals of
masculinity and femininity. It considers furthermore the gendering of social
categories such as public and private space, or artistic categories such as the
Rococo style, the nude as a genre, or professional art making itself. Looking
in particular at painting, the course will focus on works by artist such as
Boucher, Greuze, David, Girodet, Ingres, Gericault, and Delacroix<strong>.<br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2237 Relics, Saints, Images and Power - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/robert-mills" target="_self">Robert Mills</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Fridays 11am-1pm.<br />
Saints were the celebrities of
medieval Europe. From the miracles they worked to the rituals and journeys they
inspired, holy bodies were invested with immense spiritual and political power.
Relics were also hugely important as a source of aesthetic inspiration. This
course explores art and architecture associated with physical remains of
saints. Focusing especially on three cult sites in the Middle Ages – Jerusalem,
Santiago de Compostela and Canterbury – we will see how imagery associated with
saintly bodies adapts and morphs to suit the needs of different times and
places. Looking at this imagery through the prism of categories such as
translation, liminality, the simulacrum and the souvenir, the course asks how modern
critical frameworks can reconnect us with the potency of the relic. As well as
considering reliquaries and cult statues, we will explore such phenomena as mappaemundi or world maps, virtual or
armchair pilgrimage, and replica buildings designed to ‘translate’ sites
associated with the Holy Land from East to West. At the end of the course we
will also consider the afterlife of the relic. Why, in some parts of Europe,
did the power of saintly remains seemingly diminish? Where and how has it
re-emerged?<strong><br />
Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours (10 two-hour classes, including a Gallery Visit).<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500 word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience. <br /></p>

<h2 class="heading"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart2237" target="_self">Summer reading list</a></h2>






</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2239 (HAMS only) The Development and Application of Textiles in Works of Art and Artefacts - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course Tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/emma-richardson">Emma Richardson</a><strong><br />Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term: Mondays 11am-1pm.<br />
This course will combine both
theoretical and practical approaches to the understanding of textiles, their
properties and their application as artistic media. By examining the history
and development of textile, we will begin to map their usage through the
centuries to the present day, and their application within art and design. We
will explore the physical properties of fibres, yarns and textiles, investigate
the implications for fabrication, and understand what impact this has on their
visual nature. In addition to seminars and lectures, the course will include
guest speakers, and object based learning at the Victoria and Albert Museum and
The National Gallery. Additionally, practical sessions, where the student will
study the structure of fibres under the microscope, as well as extrude
synthetic fibres, will provide an appreciation for materiality and help
interpret textile artworks of various construction.<strong><br />Duration of Course:</strong> 10 weeks.<strong><br />Student
 Contact Hours:</strong> 20+ hours.<br /><strong>Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and 
back-up reading, private gallery visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />Means of 
Assessment:</strong> 2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />Prerequisites:</strong>
 Students should have completed a first-year Art History programme or 
have equivalent relevant academic experience. </p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART2242 Sense and Sensation in Early Modern Art - 0.5 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor:<strong> </strong><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/allison-stielau">Allison Stielau</a><strong><br />
Timetabled: </strong>Spring Term; Tuesdays 4-6pm.<br />Early modern art was experienced not simply
through the eyes, but also through the full range of human sense perception.
This course considers the complex web of sight, smell, touch, taste,
and sound within which artworks were embedded and out of which spectacles—like
banquets and triumphal entries—were created. Although material will be drawn
from across the continent, a particular focus rests on northern Europe in the
period 1400 to 1600. Sites for exploration of sense-experience include the
court, the street, the kitchen, the artist’s workshop, and the anatomy theatre.
The role of the senses in late medieval piety and the rejection of sensuous
worship by Protestant Reformers constitutes a significant unit of the course.
Visits to local collections and films of historical reenactment offer
opportunities for close-looking, analysis, and critique.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>10 weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>20+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload:</strong> Prescribed and back-up reading, private gallery 
visits, one essay, class presentation, and exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>2000-2,500<strong> </strong>word essay weighted at 45%; oral component 10%
and 2 hour exam in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites:  </strong>Students should have completed a first-year Art 
History programme or have equivalent relevant experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>

research project with the help and approval of the Department and 
receive guidance while undertaking the research and writing the essay. <br /></p>

 auditing and contributing to a third-stage Special Subject course. </p>

<p class="p"><strong>FINAL YEAR SPECIAL SUBJECT COURSES</strong></p>






<div id="accordion">

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3101 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: Popular and Political Cultures in Nineteenth-Century England  - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/susannah-walker">Susannah Walker</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Tuesdays 2-4pm.<br />
The
‘popular cultures’ of nineteenth-century England can feel
somewhat familiar in the image saturated present. We may find
contemporary parallels to this period's sensationalist news stories,
popular songs, flags, tattoos, religious
prints, astrological imagery, panoramas, fairs and shows. However, ‘popular
culture’ is a complex and contested term. A search for authentic culture ‘of
the people’ and debates over who controls it and who is excluded from
it remain politically charged.<br />
This
course will analyse the cultural worlds inhabited by early nineteenth
century publics using a range of theories of mass media and popular
culture. We will make close, object based studies of James
Gillray, William Blake, Thomas Bewick, George Cruikshank, J.M.W. Turner
and John Martin, considering the intersections between their artistic
ideas and the popular cultures around them.<br />
The final part of the course will look at the
challenges and possibilities of curating and communicating
nineteenth-century popular culture, making close studies of its place
in galleries and museums. Part of the assessment will
entail designing a Public Engagement project based on course
content. It is therefore a particularly suitable option for those seeking
careers in galleries or arts education.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3102 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: Russian Art and Culture: Realism and Avant-Garde - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Maria Mileeva<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Mondays 4-6pm.<br />
This course will examine
conflicts and developments in Russian and Soviet visual culture, from the turn
of the century, through the October Revolution and to the death of Stalin in
1953. Focusing on the complex relationship between art and politics during this
tumultuous period of war, revolution and social change, the course examines
aspects of rupture and continuity in the development of Russian cultural
identity. We will investigate Russian twentieth-century artists in active
dialogue with artistic developments in Europe and America, discussing case
studies of travel, exhibition, official export and emigration. We will study
Russian art both inside and outside of Russia, as its makers and commentators
crossed cultural and geographical borders making contact with artistic
developments in Paris, Berlin, Munich, and New York.<br />
The course will follow broad changes in Russian
painting, graphic art, architecture, film and design, alongside artistic
movements such as Symbolism, Primitivism, Cubofuturism, Constructivism,
Suprematism and Socialist Realism. We will consider competing and often
contradictory desires amongst artists and critics to construct a national
artistic language based on the traditions of Russian folk and icon painting,
whilst embracing aesthetic and theoretical experiments drawn from the European
avant-garde. Specific artists under investigation will include Wassily
Kandinsky, Mikhail Larionov, Natalia Goncharova, Kazimir Malevich, and El
Lissitzky, amongst others.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br /></strong><strong>Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3103 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: The Italian Avant-Garde - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/pgt-research-students/flavia-frigeri">Flavia Frigeri</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Tuesdays 4-6pm.<br />This course is an advanced undergraduate course on the history of the Italian
avant-garde, with an emphasis on key political debates, aesthetic developments,
and experimental practices in Italian Modernism and post-war art. It is taught
in tandem with the research resources in London.<br />
The course will
unfold chronologically. Starting with Divisionism and ending with Arte Povera
it will map the development of modern and post-war Italian art. Seminal
movements such as Futurism, Metaphysical Art, Informel and Arte Povera will be
tackled along with in focus classes devoted to singular artists, such as
Giorgio Morandi, Lucio Fontana and Michelangelo Pistoletto, amongst others.
Attention will also be given to contemporary developments in the fields of
design and film and how these in turn inflected the dialogue around art.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3104 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: Modern and Contemporary: The Body and its Vicissitudes - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: Rye Holmboe<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Fridays 11am-1pm.<br />
This course examines
notions of embodiment in performance through its interdisciplinary relationship
with dance, theatre, painting, sculpture, and
video/television in modern and contemporary art. We consider the
mobilisation of the body as a critique of bourgeois modernity. Equally, we analyse
performance and embodiment as therapeutic, pedagogical or transformative
processes, and as attempts to form different modes of consciousness. Some
of the areas explored include: Antonin Artaud and the Theatre of Cruelty;
Isadora Duncan and the advent of free dance; Samuel Beckett, absurdity and
negation; the figure of the marionette in the history of modern art;
performance and counterculture in the 1960s, particularly as it relates to
anti-psychiatry; the place of performance within feminist art; the
relationship between gender identification, race and queer
subjectivity; the current interest in dance within contemporary art;
and the positioning of performance within participation and relational
aesthetics.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3105 Advanced Undergraduate Course in the History of Art: The Early Modern Technologies of Vision - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: Rosemary Moore<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Wednesdays 11am-1pm.<br />
 This course will examine
the impact of new technologies of vision (for example: print, optical lenses,
systems of perspective etc.) and ask: how did these shape the production and
dissemination of knowledge in early modern Europe? From botanical illustrations
by Dürer to studies of the human anatomy by Leonardo, Raphael and other
artists, we will examine artworks that seem to suggest a renewed interest in
the study of the natural world, along with woodcuts and engravings from medical
or ‘scientific’ treatises. Some of the earliest known European images of the
landscapes and peoples of the so called ‘New World’ of the Americas will also
be addressed. Print will be central to our discussion of these ‘new
technologies of vision’ and while it is often conceptualised as a medium that
transmits clear, verifiable and accurately replicable information about the
world, we will also consider some of the problems that this language masks.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3205 Art and Visual Culture in Early Modern England - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/diana-dethloff">Diana Dethloff</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Thursdays 2-4pm.<br />
This course examines art
production, patronage and performance in the formative period of Britain’s
artistic history, covering the period from 1558 to c. 1650. Topics will
include: the importance of the visual arts in the ‘cult’ of monarchy, in
particular Elizabeth I; ephemeral spectacles such as masques, progresses and
courtly entertainments; the representation of power and authority; the
representation of women; the representation of dress and fashion; the influence
of continental practice on English art and architecture; printed and medallic
imagery; studio training and workshop practice; the effects of the Civil War on
established patronage systems and art collecting and the beginnings of an art
market.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience. <br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3221 Technologies in Art - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff" target="_self">Matilde Nardelli</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Thursdays 4-6pm.<br />
This
course explores the relation between the moving image and art from the
beginning of the 20th century to the present, providing a historical and critical
context for the ‘cinematic turn’ of contemporary art and the diffusion of the
moving image in culture at large. Though the course follows a roughly
chronological order, the sessions are arranged thematically, exploring a number
of theoretical concerns in the history of the moving image, and the way in
which these concerns are articulated in a diverse body of moving-image works
spanning from classics of the historical avant-garde and experimental cinema
such as René Clair’s Entr’acte (1924) and Hollis Frampton’s (nostalgia) (1971)
to video art, contemporary gallery installations and internet-based films.
Taking as its main focus the – changing – material base of the moving image,
from the celluloid of photochemical cinema to the digital code of contemporary
video, the course will not only trace a history of the moving image in art, but
also introduce some of the ways in which such image has been theorized as art.
Through analysis of a range of works and critical texts (from ‘theories’ of the
moving image to reflections on the medium on the part of practitioners
themselves) we will situate debates about the sometimes contested status of the
moving image as art, its aesthetics and materiality, its novelty and
obsolescence, against the wider horizon of technological and media changes and
their cultural impact.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>
<p class="p"><a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/prospective-students/course-descriptions/reading-lists/hart3221">Summer reading list</a><br /></p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3226 Architecture and the Modern City - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">   Course tutor: Jacob Paskins<strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Tuesdays 11am-1pm.<br />Architecture is
inhabitable, multi-dimensional space. But film, photography, drawings and texts
provide much of our understanding of architecture and the modern city. This
course asks what different forms of architectural dissemination can tell us
about the design and meaning of buildings and urban space. How does cinema,
television and radio represent architecture to a mass public? How has
architecture become a touchstone in the art of comics? How do written texts
including guidebooks and magazines communicate architectural knowledge to
diverse audiences? How do manifestos and the architecture book transmit new
ideas about architectural design? Asking these questions, we will explore how
historians have used these different modes of architectural representation to
write the history of architecture in the twentieth century. Finally, we will
consider how these varied artefacts continue to inspire architecture and urban
design.<br /><strong>Duration of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3235 Documentary Work: American Media in the 1930s - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p"> Course tutor: Simon Constantine<br /><strong>Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Mondays 2-4pm.<br />
This course examines the rise of documentary practice in the United
States in the 1930s. Framed by the U.S. government’s systematic use of
photography as means to remedy the Depression and orchestrate Franklin D.
Roosevelt’s New Deal, the course organizes a media history of documentary
work—in books, films, and illustrated magazines. Students will be encouraged to
mine the overlaps and intersections between these media, and to develop a
history of documentary practices in the United States that exceeds the strictures
of modernism’s medium specificities. In addition to bridging the gap between
histories of media and exploring the relationship between the rise of
documentary work and the emergence of new mass media, this course also aims to
address the multiple and radical politics of documentary film and photography
in America. Course materials include the books, films, and illustrated
portfolios produced by America’s documentary vanguard, including Walker Evans,
Margaret Bourke-White, Paul Strand, and Pare Lorentz, as well as more recent
studies of documentary practices and media histories.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3241 Psycho - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/mignon-nixon">Mignon Nixon</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Thursdays 11am-1pm.<br />
From the
Surrealist revolution to the present, art, film, and visual culture have seized
on radical ideas of psychoanalysis to articulate—to connect—subjectivity and
politics. The unconscious, the symptom, hysteria, polymorphous perversity, the
death drive, the uncanny, fetishism, melancholia, resistance and transference
are just some of the psychoanalytic propositions that inform the making and the
interpretation of critical modes of art from Freud’s time to our own. This
course looks at dynamic interactions of art, psychoanalysis, and politics. It
also considers dissident theories and practices of psychoanalysis in the
perspective of representation. It involves in-depth reading of psychoanalytic
texts and of art-historical and critical literature in which psychoanalysis is
brought to bear. Particular emphasis is given to discourses of feminism and
gender in their critical engagement with psychoanalysis and to psychoanalytic
theories of violence and war.<br /><strong>Duration
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

<dt class="accordion__title"><a href="#">HART3242 Early Modern Metamorphosis - 1.0 cu</a></dt>
<dd class="accordion__description" style="display: none;">
     <div>
<p class="p">Course tutor: <a href="https://www.ucl.ac.uk/art-history/people/academic-staff/allison-stielau">Allison Stielau</a><strong><br />
Timetabled</strong>: Autumn and Spring terms; Mondays 11am-1pm.<br />
Metamorphosis—the
total change of one form into another—has been a major subject of art
since antiquity. This course takes up topics of metamorphosis in
early modern art and material culture. The first term will focus on the
representation of transformation. Students will become familiar both with
Ovid’s Metamorphoses (in modern and early modern translation) and
with responses to that text by artists ranging from Pollaiuolo, Bernini, and
Rubens to anonymous masters in all media. We seek to understand the appeal
and the challenge of transformation for the visual artist. In the second term
we will consider physical and conceptual transformations of artworks
themselves. Topics include processes of conversion and secularization,
adaptation and recycling, the recovery and reframing of spolia (ancient fragments), and the shifting purposes and meanings
of artworks through time and across varied cultural contexts.<strong><br />Duration</strong><strong>
 of Course:  </strong>20+ weeks.<strong><br />
Student Contact Hours: </strong>40+ hours.<strong><br />
Student Workload: </strong>Prescribed and back-up reading, class 
presentation, private gallery visits, 2 essays, exam.<strong><br />
Means of Assessment: </strong>Two
2000–2,500 word essays weighted at 45%; oral component 10% and a 3 hour exam
in exam term weighted at 45%.<strong><br />
Prerequisites: </strong>Completion of 2nd-year History of Art course or 
equivalent relevant  experience.</p>

</div>
  </dd>
        
    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
    

    
</dl>
 

</div>
